text: Bar none one of the best restaurants I've had the chance to eat at so far in NYC. Not only is the food diverse and incredible, the service is attentive, humorous and engaging. The space is relatively small and intimate; we were seated at the bar, but never felt too close or crowded out by other patrons. For the size, the noise management is fairly good too.For appetizers we ordered the caviar on sprint toast with wasabi aioli and the octopus. Both were incredible and I was amazed by the crunchy delicacy the shrimp toast had. Think of a fried shrimp ball from your favorite dim sum restaurant, but with an airy and crispy texture, and then topped with caviar to balance out the dish. Incredible.For our main course, we ordered the Scallops, Pig Out, and the special, which was a type of game which tasted similar to duck. Scallops were well seared and complimented the lentils and foam well, however the leftover lentils by themselves left something to be desired. The Pig Out and special were a parade of textures and flavors, from crunchy to fork-tender, and umami to spicy. The sides of Japanese Sweet Potato and Sticky Rice just helped to round everything out.It was a delectable meal for two for a decent price and I'll definitely be back to clear the rest of the menu!
Amazing dinner here with friends. The pork was delicious but that snow crab pasta...lawd have mercy. Beautiful on the inside and worthy of the michelin star. Def check it out

Overall, Tuome is great.  I really wanted to give it 5 stars, but alas it wasn't an A+ meal.  I'll list the hits & missesHits: - Service is great.  My waitress was attentive / knowledgeable / all that you can ask for in a server.  - Chicken Liver was really good.  Of course we needed more bread so that we could lick the plate clean haha.  - Reasonable menu prices for the quality of food - Broccoli side dish.  I don't know what was in the sauce but I could've drunken it.  Misses- Pig out for two.  I reaaaalllly wanted to love this dish, but I found it very average and not worth the hype.  Even with the garlic & sriracha toppings, the whole dish felt very pedestrian.  Ugh.  The noodles were good though. - Chinese Beignets.  Again, I realllly wanted to love this dessert, but it was just OK for me.  I think I love the vanilla ice cream the most.  The caramel sauce tasted very lite to me.  Overall, it was a great experience, and Tuome is a great restuarant.  Will I be back though?  Not entirely sure.  Still, for what it is, I'd recommend Tuome to others.
The food is excellent, so is the service. A fusion restaurant doesn't always tempt diners but this one is unique in the fact that the combinations are creative and work well. Definitely recommended!

It's hard to sell me on Asian fusion, but I love Tuome. I get the same thing every time I come here, because it's so amazing I can never bring myself to try other things on the menu! To start, get the chicken liver mousse. I'm not the biggest foie gras/pate person, but this dish is incredible. The texture is so fluffy and light, which is great in contrast to the really rich, umami flavors of the chicken liver. You spread it on perfectly toasted squares of bread, with some sea salt and maple syrup. HEAVEN. I've also had the octopus with XO sauce, which is very good, but not as life-changing as the chicken liver mousse.Then you need the pig out for two -- this is some crispy squares of pork belly, a bowl of peanut noodles, and a little citrusy side salad. I am very picky when it comes to pork belly (it's generally too fatty for me), but I could eat this for days. The peanut sauce coating the noodles is also incredible. For dessert, get the beignets which come with goat's milk caramel. Ugh. So good.  I also really love the vibe of this restaurant. It's quiet, cozy, and feels like a neighborhood place. And it's never difficult to get a reservation or do a walk-in, even during prime time!
Small charming restaurant with amazing food. Definitely worthy of a Michelin star!

Love everything on this menu literally. I went with 6 people and order everything on the menu. Everything was excellent. It was so amazing I went again 5 days later. Make sure to get the crisp pork for two and the crab noodles. Great food! Great service.

Such a gem! A cute and cozy restaurant with completely mind-blowing food. We were a party four, completely blown away by the quality of the food and wine. It was my birthday and the restaurant manager prepared a special dessert for me (what a special treat! and it wasn't on the bill!). Highly recommended.

Came for restaurant week with a group of four and did a mix of RW and regular menu. We all shared:+ Quack on brioche+ cauliflower with blue cheese miso( RW menu)+ chicken liver (RW menu)+ pig out for 2 (RW menu)+ Wagyu beef steak+ Snow crab noodles+ Japanese sweet potato+ Rice with duck sausage and kale+ chocolate torte (RW menu)+ Chinese beignets (RW menu)Highlight was the snow crab noodles, hands down. Other standouts were the chicken liver and Japanese sweet potato. Pig out was great, too. Definitely would return just for those noodles!!

This restaurant is not what you would expect as it's in the heart of Alphabet City, on a relatively quiet street, but boy is it a gem in disguise. It recently received a one Michelin star rating for it's unique take on Chinese-inspired American food. This is a tapas style type of place, so definitely order a decent amount! I'd say 4-5 dishes make the perfect serving size for a couple ready for an amazing dining experience.For my first appetizer, I ordered the octopus. The dish is an art in itself as the brown butter is dished out in front of you from an icing style type of can. The second appetizer I got was the cauliflower dish with blue cheese miso, grape and herbs. This was amazing. The blue cheese miso kept your mouth guessing and pleasantly surprised as the saltiness of the miso coupled with the blue cheese added a nice punch.As for my main dish, I got the Pig Out (for two) and shared it with my boyfriend. This is the one dish here that is meant for two people, so the serving was much bigger. It also comes with garlic QQ noodles which were such a good pairing for the friend pork that had a sticky candied top. Definitely a must try! The salad on the side was probably one of the BEST arugula-based salads I've ever had. It had this sweet lychee-based dressing with candied walnuts and real lychees throughout. This dish was a gem and truly stood out to me.We didn't realize at first this dish came with noodles, so we decided to also order the rice, which was definitely a great option. This sticky rice was served classic Chinese style in the banana leaves. It had Chinese sausage and was steamed with duck fat. So rich and so flavorful.Highly recommend this spot and will definitely go back.
Asian fusion food but very yummy. Nice cool atmosphere and the peanutbutter noodles were mind blowing.  Had never tried anything like that before.

This review is almost a year late, so I am not going to remember all the details. :'( I do remember, however, that we had a reservation for 6 people for 9:30PM (which is late already as it is) but we were kept waiting until 10:30PM. The management gave us several bottles of wine to appease us, which did help for my friends, but not for me because I don't drink any alcohol at all. After that harrowing experience, the reason that Tuome gets above 2 stars from me is really the crab noodles - they were stupendous. They were easily one of the best dishes I've ever had in my life. Even over a year later, I remember this dish being incredibly memorable, delicious and thought-provoking. I really want to come back on an early weeknight to avoid the wait (so I'd recommend you do that, if possible) and enjoy the crab noodles again. Raymond and I also shared the pig out for two, which I had been really excited for after seeing a detailed explanation on a video online. It sounded absolutely amazing, and it's definitely very thoughtfully executed, but it failed to wow me because it was pretty comparable to excellent siu yook in Hong Kong (that costs 1/10 of the price for a larger portion). It's definitely better than any siu yook I've had, and each piece was truly equal parts tender, fatty and crispy, but the marginal taste experience difference did not make up for the shockingly large price difference. It's definitely good, though, and worth the price for the amount of effort and overall tastiness. It also comes with a bowl of noodles and is very filling; I think this is definitely enough for two people. So in the grand scheme of things, this is a quite reasonably priced meal for two.Overall, I would really just come back for the crab noodles and see if there's anything else I want to try. I had Chef Thomas Chen's dish at the MOFAD and I loved it, so I know I like his food. I'm definitely willing to give it another try.

My fiancé and I saw a last minute opening on a Saturday night for bar seating and we grabbed it right away, as someone must've just cancelled.  we had a very nice experience, with wonderful food and attentive service.My fiancé has a difficult time with restaurant that have Asian influences given his celiac disease but they were very knowledgeable here and we were able to order many things to share that were gluten free.The spiced curry popcorn with lime zest that they give you is very flavorful and a wonderful way to star the meal.The wagyu tartare was incredibly fresh and well executed (they just had to put the crisps on the side since they contained gluten).  The chicken liver was very sweet and tasty.The pork for 2 was incredible, so crispy and not too fatty, and gluten free!  The sauces on the side were awesome as well.  They were able to substitute the noodles with a sweet potato dish for my fiancé that had mashed potatoes (or butter) drizzled on top they were delicious.  The noodles I got were amazing, with a very strong peanut flavor that complemented everything.We would definitely come back!
Outstanding food in a nice intimate setting. I've been here three times and loved each time. The fried pork with peanut butter asian noodles is a must.

I don't normally like to go to a restaurant twice but this place is somewhere I'd go again. The ambiance is very romantic, though a little drafty. I didn't mind the drafty windows, just placed my coat on my back. The building is very old and the restaurant reflects this, small, closed off spaces but it really lends itself to the romantic atmosphere. The decor is dark, Asian but I'm not an interior decorator...the food was incredible with some misses due to the boldness of the menu, especially the Berkshire pork dish. This dish was so rich and decadent I wanted to fall asleep after I ate it. They took some pork meat, chopped it up then stacked chopped up skin, pressed it down tight, crisped up the skin and cut it in small "bite-sized" squares. They paired it with a salad and peanut noodles. I enjoyed this dish very much although there were some flaws which I hope they perfected. It was so heavy but was lacking in vinegar, acidic element to cut the fat. The salad was tasty but I thought the candied walnuts went rancid. I LOVE candied nuts SO much and I couldn't eat them. I still recommend it

Pretty decent experience, the majority of dishes was heavily flavored, a lot of cream, blue cheese, butter etc, the pig out was particularly heavy... we ate a bit more than half of the plate and just gave up, not because we were full or it didn't taste well, it was just too much for the stomach to handle at once lolThe rice wrapped in lotus leafs(?) was very authentic imo, enjoyed that very much as well as the cauliflower (just wish there wasn't so much blue cheese)Overall a very decent dinner, tables were very close to each other which was a bit awkward, but it's nyc, we are used to it (sort of), the place gets filled up rather quickly, so definitely make a reservation

Friend and I randomly found Tuome and had one of the best dinners. We dined at the bar and ordered octopus, cauliflower, chicken porridge, crab noodles, side of carrots and beignet ice cream to top it all off! Every dish from the first bite to the last was impeccably executed.  Not only were the flavors robust leaving you wanting more but there is clearly a lot of thought to the texture of the dish.  I live in the 90s but will be heading down here again!Great date spot or dinner with friends!

This place is the whole package! I took my best friend for her birthday last week and we both left with very happy bellies!  First off, I highly recommend that everyone make a reservation.  If not, you may end up waiting for a while.  The food was perfect.  The pig out was unbelievable.  Just soooo good.  We got the liver mousse and the fried deviled eggs to start then the Pig out for two as a main.  It was enough food for the two of us.  Who could have thought that deviled eggs could be this amazing!  Seriously, Give this place a try!  The drinks and staff are also great but the food here is outstanding.

Definitely make a reservation if you're planning to come on a weekend (we got denied on a Sat night one time), but on a regular Tues evening, it was empty! The dining experience is on the romantic side with very dim lighting. FOOD:Egg (deviled): Tbh probably the highlight of my meal!! Perfectly crispy and pipin' hot on the outside and the chili sauce was a fantastic twist to this classic appetizer. Quack on brioche: Duck was cooked really well. Brioche was buttery. A bit saucey for me, so I wish there were more daikon relish in mine but other than that I enjoyed this appetizer. Pig Out (for two): Comes with 12 pieces of crispy pork, arugula, 2 bowls of peanut noodles, and 2 condiments for the pork. I could tell that the pork was cooked exquisitely and the skin was actually super crunchy. Under the layer of crispy skin, the pork was like a pulled-pork texture (not like the pork belly from Chinese butcher shops). The peanut butter noodles were cooked al dente which is just the way I like it! Got a bit saucey as well though. For $58, I don't know if I would pay that much for it again, but nonetheless the whole dish was cooked well. SERVICE: Everyone was very attentive and refilled our water once it was half empty! I like how they explain every dish to you as well.

We went to Tuome for restaurant week, and were absolutely blown away!The Food: 5/5. We shared the roasted cauliflower (5/5), chicken liver mousse (4/5), snow crab noodles with truffle ($13 supplement) (5/5), and amish chicken (5/5). We agreed that the snow crab noodles were easily top 3 dishes we've had in New York thus far. We rarely order chicken when eating out, but the server highly recommended it, so we gave it a try. This was probably the BEST chicken I've ever had. It was cooked perfectly and utterly delicious. The Service: 5/5. The server was friendly and attentive throughout the whole meal.I get a little nervous going to Michelin star restaurants during restaurant week and fear that the experience will be a bit diluted. THIS WAS NOT THE CASE. Tuome totally lived up to the hype, and the food was everything we hoped it would be. Only minor complaint is that it was FREEZING outside and they did not seem to appropriately adjust the heat inside. The experience would have been perfect if they turned up the heat - the cold was a bit distracting during the meal. However, we will certainly go back to try their Pig Out (for two) in the near future!

The octopus appetizer is to die for! The night we went, they offered black truffles on top so we opted for it. It was perfect on top of the potato puree, so divine. The joong, Chinese tamale, or "rice" side dish was pretty great, a cute reminder of the ones I eat back home. Everything else we ordered was lacking - the pork belly, sesame noodles, and the deviled eggs. The pork belly was basically pulled pork shaped into a cube and fried until crispy on the outside - not a real Cantonese pork belly. I will say the portion was huge, we couldn't even finish the entire thing. However, it was really really fatty. I don't think the sesame noodles was a good pairing because the pork was already so heavy. I wish we had more of the arugula salad because that made eating the pork belly more bearable. The octopus really stole the show and made me excited for the rest of the meal. Unfortunately, the rest just didn't deliver, so we passed on dessert.
Tuome:Recommendation:1.SNOW CRAB2.PIG OUT (FOR TWO)3.BEIGNET(dessert, fried bun with red bean ice cream)

My husband and I came here for an anniversary dinner, and we both agreed it was one of the best places we've eaten at together. It's a quaint place - very cozy, dim lighting, exposed brick wall. The vibe is warm and comfortable. You can tell it's a nice restaurant without being too upscale. We decided to order off the prefix menu that included 3 dishes. We got the chicken liver, pig out for two, and beignets. We also ordered the cauliflower as an extra app. Each dish was more delicious than the last. If you love suckling pig, the pig out for two is a must-get! It also comes with peanut noodles. They also included a cute message saying happy anniversary when they brought out our dessert. It's a great place for a date or small get-together, and definitely a place we'll be going back to!

We came here for the restaurant week. The place is cute and dark. Service was good. I ordered chicken liver for starter, it was very smooth and tasty. Steak tartar is also decent. We shared pig out as main. It was good initially, but feels it's a bit too rich and greasy towards the end. I had beignet as dessert. It's amazing. Everything tastes good, but it's a bit too rich for me overall. Worth going at least once, especially during restaurant week, it was a good deal

Did anyone come here on Valentine's Day this week and get sick? My husband felt very nauseous after our meal (which another Yelp review from Valentine's Day also mentioned), and I'm pretty certain I have food poisoning. The food and service were good but not sure about the after effects...

TLDR; I do not recommend coming here for a prix fixe menu (except maybe RW?) but yes for the regular menuWe came here for the valentines day 5-course menu. The ambience and service was great but the actual prix fixe menu was not. A lot of their items I really wanted to try that they are known for were not on the menu and some of the dishes served were not good. We asked for their recommendation on a red wine. I specified I wanted something sweet but not too sweet. The wine we were recommended was too light and too sweet it tasted like diluted grape juice. Course 1 is the fluke, which is a type of fish. The sauce on the fish was amazing as was the 2 chips they gave us. The amount of fish though was maybe 3-4 thin, small slivers, adding up to maybe one or two pieces of nigiri you might get from a regular sushi restaurant. Course 2 is the caviar on shrimp toast and sun choke soup. It was overly salty. Course 3 is the crab noodles, which were absolutely heavenly. There was very little crab but the sauce and the noodles were the real MVPs and the portion was big. Course 4 is the wagyu, which also was amazing but the sauces were a little salty. Course 5 is the chocolate tart, which tasted like a dryer, more bitter and heavier version of Royce chocolates. It was not good. Not sure why but me and my bf also felt really nauseous afterwards. At the end, they took a Polaroid of us to commemorate the occasion which I thought was super cute!So was this worth the $150pp? Definitely not since only two of the dishes were worth getting (and combined cost less than half of the price). Some of the items were really good though so I would definitely urge people to come and order off the regular menu since you can choose exactly what you want and it'd be a lot cheaper. I'm a bit disappointed since I had been wanting to come here for a long time but I think my experience might've been better if I had come on a regular evening.

Fantastic restaurant week dinner and experience! We arrived at 6:30pm on Monday and it was empty but it filled up quickly by 7pm. The ambiance was cozy and intimate. Perfect for a date. The food took a little long to arrive but the service was outstanding! - Chicken liver mousse: WOW! This was incredible. The mousse was so smooth and full of flavor. It paired nicely with the side condiments and white toasted bread. They also provide more bread if needed. - Beef tartare: Not my favorite. It was good but I didn't feel the two hour yolk was special. The beef itself was too chewy for me. - Snow crab noodles: SO DELICIOUS! It came with plenty of crab. The egg noodles had the most perfect texture and the dashi butter was bursting with flavor without it being overly salty. - Chocolate tart: Average. It was super dense almost too dry for my liking. Might suit someone who loves chocolate. - Beignet: Incredible asian influence on this. The fried buns were warm paired with cream goat milk ice cream and caramel. The dish was sort of DIY which made it fun to eat. Highly recommend! Oh did I mention a bottle of wine (red, white, rosé) was only $35?? Take advantage of restaurant week specials. BUT regardless I am dyinggg to return!

What an excellent restaurant! The flavors, food, service and overall experience was amazing and well worth the visit. I highly recommend both the Chicken and Snow Crab entrees as they were both delicious! Going here is definitely the right choice!

One of my favorite dinner spots!! Must gets: deviled eggs, quail, chicken entree, and snow crab noodles. The snow crab noodles are my favorite. Noodles are a perfect al dente and coated with the right amount of sauce.

Came here for restaurant week. I got the chicken liver mousse, snow crab, and beignet. The chicken liver mousse tasted closer to butter than chicken liver. The snow crab was good, but towards the end it became a little too salty. I liked the dessert best!I also tried some of the pig out. The peanut noodles were slightly spicy and was really heavy. I've definitely had better peanut noodles at Asian places. The pork for the pig out was extremely oily. Personally, I would have liked it if the each cut was smaller.

Two main surprises from Tuome: NOT it's pig out, but it's fried chickens and beignets. They are the must-eat. Beignets are heavenly when they are served hot, alongside with ice cream! You probably can't find similar fried chickens and beignets in other NYC eateries.

Middle of the road experience. Be prepared to wait a while even though you have a reservation. We came on time and waited for over 20 minutes. We had to ask for wine while we waited and the staff seemed turned off by that. Once seated there were dirty utensils under our table. Ordered the cauliflower for starters and the chicken for the main. The portions were generous and tasty. The popcorn starter was a throwaway and cold. Overall good experience but not something I'd go back to.

If I could give this restaurant more stars, I would. Not only is the atmosphere cozy and romantic, but the food is also some of the most unique, tastiest food I have ever had and the service was great too. The chef is definitely very talented, and came up with very unusual flavors for sauces and dishes, etc. The snow crab noodle entree was incredible!!!!! Probably the best noodles I have ever had. Moral of the story- go to Tuome!!! You will not regret it.

First time dining here and it was a wonderful experience through and through. Overall service was great and the manager Andrew even came over to our table and suggested a natural wine that would pair with our dishes, and we loved it! We started off with two small dishes: the octopus and hamachi (not pictured but worth the try) and then ordered the entree of the snow crab pasta which was my favorite- super yummy and tasty! For dessert, i world recommend the beignets and making them into a ice cream sandwich style (as they suggested). Overall a great choice of delicious food items, knowledgeable and welcoming staff! Can't wait to visit the NY area again and stop by!!

Ok so let me start off by saying the service and ambiance deserves five stars.I came here for restaurant week on a Friday evening and our meal started with complimentary popcorn. The curry popcorn kind of reminded me of Indian food. It was a nice idea but I didn't particularly care for the specific flavor combination and it was served warm or at room temperature, perhaps it would have been better hot. Still, it was complimentary so I appreciated the gesture. I had the chicken liver as the appetizer. It was quite creamy and light at the same time, which I enjoyed. On the side, sea salt was given which added a nice pairing to it. My friend had the cauliflower appetizer and I tried a bit of her sauce for it and it was simply sublime. I actually think the tiny morsel of sauce from her cauliflower was the most delectable part of the meal for me.As an entree, I was kind of disappointed that the pig out had to be for two as my friend did not want it/was not in the mood for it... meaning I could not try it. We both had the snow crab and we were both a little let down. My friend immediately commented that the "snow crab" was more of a minor garnish. The butter flavor to the noodles was nice in a subtle manner. At that point, I mentioned to my friend that I could not really pinpoint or taste the Chinese influence as strongly as I was hoping or initially imagined. My friend was shocked! She could not believe that it was a Chinese-American fusion as she said she hadn't tasted anything Chinese at all. I showed her the type of cuisine on yelp as it's listed and she still couldn't fathom it. For this reason, I would definitely say (at least with the dishes we ordered), the Chinese flavorings were not immediately recognizable or coming through. For the dessert, one of us had the beignet and the other had the chocolate tart and we shared both. The chocolate was too dark and rich for me personally but if you enjoy dark chocolate, you would like it as it was very rich. My friend felt the beignets were just okay as she commented that they could have been softer and they did not resemble beignets as typically seen in New Orleans at the Cafe du Monde or something of the sort. I really enjoyed the flavor of the ice cream as well as the caramel topping which came with the desserts. I think overall, the food was three stars for me personally.

No wonder it's Michelin worthy! I came here for restaurant week ($42/person) and left with both my heart and my stomach full. This is a really great place for delicious food in a very intimate atmosphere that's perfect for a date or to catch up with a good friend. We ended up ordering:+ chicken liver mousse+ wagyu beef tartare+ pig out (for two)+ chocolate+ Chinese beignetsEvery single bite of food and every single component of each dish had its own bursting flavor profile but I would say that the chicken liver mousse was the highlight of the night! The beef tartare was also really refreshing and delicate but there was something so intoxicating about the chicken liver mousse.When you order the pig out, each person gets their own bowl of peanut noodles and I really appreciated how chewy/al dente the noodles still were. The pork itself was skillfully prepared. I'm usually hesitant to order pork at a restaurant but it was as if they had deconstructed it. The meat was very tender and flaky (is that even a thing) while the skin was super crispy (my fav).The chocolate is a bit heavy so definitely do share. It worked out well to eat it with the vanilla ice cream that came with the beignets. I loved the citron jam (reminds me of the Korean tea) and the goat's milk caramel (tangy but still sweet).All in all, I really enjoyed my experience here and would love to come try some of their other dishes! The food is beautifully presented but the flavor profiles remind me of some of my favorite childhood dishes.

We went to Tuome for the fourth time and I'm finally confident to say that this is my favorite restaurant in the city, period. We were here this time for restaurant week, and their restaurant week menu offers their regular dishes and the quality was amazing as usual.I have to say, I am reminded every time I come here, with every dish, how much thought and love they put behind their food - they are innovative, modern and beautiful plated, yet, they all bring back memories of food my grandma cooked, my dad cooked, something once so popular at restaurant when I was kid in Beijing. The dining experience here is an orgasmic feast accompanied with waves of childhood memories. It can't get any better than this.

Rule Number 1 of eating at Tuome: Do everything the chef recommends. If you've never been to Tuome, get ready for dark, moodily-lit space and some stellar Asian-fusion fare.We started off with drinks and were gifted a complimentary mini bowl of cumin and lime zest popcorn. Eat this. I immediately warmed to the establishment because popcorn forms the base of my personal food pyramid (along with peanut butter and coffee).At the time of this review, it's restaurant week, so we ordered off that menu. The chicken liver mousse with milk bread was very nice, as was the wagyu beef tartare with a "two hour egg yolk" and crispy chips. I truly have no idea what a two hour egg yolk is, but I can report that the crispy chips are, in fact, deep fried wonton bits and furthermore, they are downright delightful. Next up was the pork belly. The chef recommends using both the confit and lime chili sauce on each bite of pork. Do that. I marveled aloud that I've never had pork belly that quite so crunchy, at which point my boyfriend pointed out that the crispy part was actually pork skin. Mystery solved. (Don't let that deter you if you're squeamish about non-conventional meat parts--it's delicious and more of a texture than a flavor). The accompanying noodles had peanut sauce (another win for my food pyramid!) and overall the dish was excellent. I experienced a fleeting moment of doubt because the noodle portions appeared small, but the dish was rich and very filling. If your server asks if you'd like accompanying sides, you can safely pass unless you've just finished a half marathon or fasted all day. Beignets and a chocolate tart rounded out the meal. The chef recommends that you make the beignets, ice cream, and goat milk caramel into mini ice cream sandwiches. Do that. I pulled the middle out of my beignet, which was a cross between a croissant and a traditional beignet, and proceeded to enjoy the best ice cream sandwich I've had since the stroopwafel ice cream sandwiches I used to buy in Colorado. The tart was accompanied with crunchy almond bits, rich in a flourless chocolate cake kind of way, and not to sweet, but if I could go back in time, I would get mounds of those beignets with ice cream.

My partner and I saw tuome online and thought it was a cool (but also weird) concept to incorporate traditional American food with Chinese food, so we decided to stop by for dinner one night. The service wasn't bad, but it wasn't great. We walked in and it was packed that night, so we were told that we would have to wait. That wasn't a problem. I would have liked for the waitress to be more attentive, though. It was like she took our order, brought our food, and that was it. She wasn't around when we needed more drinks or wanted to order more food. The food on the other hand was very yummy. The deviled eggs were breaded and crispy, and I can say confidently that they were some of the best deviled eggs I've ever had. The seafood dish I ordered was too yummy! It was creamy and packed with flavor. The chef was not shy on the amount of seafood they put in, too!Besides the waitress that went missing, I'd go back for everything!

Came here for our first stop of restaurant week! Overall we were very impressed with all of the dishes, but the chicken liver mousse, Berkshire pork and beignets really stood out!We ordered chicken liver and wagyu beef tartar for the appetizers. Chicken liver was so smooth and creamy -- smeared over a warm piece of toast, it almost tasted like a very rich butter. I could eat that all night! The beef wasn't as tasty in comparison. Next was the Berkshire pork for two served with peanut sauce noodles. The pork reminded me of crispy pork belly skin on top of something similar in texture to pulled pork. Paired with the sauces and the chewy peanut noodles, it was an interesting and delightful entree. Dessert we ordered the beignets and chocolate mousse. The restaurant week menu online offers apple almond tarte but this wasn't offered in the store, and my waitress said the online menu may be from a previous year. Darn! I like to plan what I'm ordering ahead of time for restaurant week so I was pretty disappointed that the menu wasn't up to date - but it's hard to be upset when everything else was so tasty. Anyway if I could do it again, I'd make it two orders of the beignet. The chocolate mousse was very rich and there was nothing wrong with it, but it just didn't compare to the beignets. They were almost like mini croissants, still warm, and we were told to cut them in half and make an ice cream sandwich with the vanilla ice cream and caramel sauce (which came in the cutest little condiment bottle). Overall, I would highly recommend Tuome! I'd make a res as it's a small space and seemed to be packed even on a Monday night when it temperatures were in the low teens!!

I thoroughly enjoyed everything we tried on the menu, (all but 2 items). A few of the standouts were the Pig Out, Wagyu, fried deviled eggs!, and the ! Veggie options were available and also delicious! 10/10 would go again/ recommend!
The food at this place was good but service was super slow. We had a reservation but still have to wait for a table. Food here is mainly American with a twist of Asian.

Glad I finally was able to try this place. We went on a Thursday at 8:30p. We had to make reservations a week in advanced. Tuome's already popular and it's gotten even more traction since it made the Michelin list for 2019. This gem of a restaurant's in the east village - dim light, exposed brick, and some wood interior. It's the perfect date spot / intimate spot. We sat at the bar and the servers were super friendly and attentive. Food highlights below: - octopus -- deliciously charred, soft and juicy in the middle. The sauce paired is thick and delicious. - pig out for two -- this gives you 12 pieces of crispy pork belly. It's cooked in duck fat which gives the pork an extra depth of flavor. For the pork, there are two sauces - one is grated ginger and the other is chili oil. Would suggest eating with both sauces. This dish is paired with a salad that's refreshing, and peanut noodles on the side. It's thick and sweet - I loved it. - sticky rice with Chinese sausage - this is an underrated dish. I think it was my favorite dish of the night too. It's steamed in a leaf with duck fat, so the rice is full of flavor. I couldn't stop eating this.I can't believe it took us this long to go to Tuome. It's a well deserved star, and I'll be going back regularly. Looking forward to trying their snow crab and cauliflower dish and exploring their wine options.

The food here is excellent! I didn't expect to like the Snow Crab noodles but they were addictive. And the quail and deviled egg appetizers were delicious! I found the cocktail I had (Fire something) overly sweet but the wines were very good. Definitely give this place a try!

Went the other night and was blown away!!  First, when they saw my dad coming in with a walker, they moved us right by the door and throughout, they were very accommodating.  The place is cozy and relatively quiet, making conversation quite easy.  But the outstanding part is the food.  Between the presentation, the mix of textures, and the flavors - truly an epicurean delight!!

Had a great nye dinner here. They served prefixed meals on that night. The chef started us with butternut squash soup and it's very creamy and delicious. Then we had the fluke crudo which has coconut milk and lemon sauce on top which makes it super yummy. Then we had Brussel sprouts and I think it's the best brussel sprouts I have ever had in my life and I'm not a big fan of brussel sprouts. Then we had the snow crab egg noodles which tasted like caramel and butter and it's just melt in your mouth!!! it was definitely the best dish there. We had the steak as our main course which was just ok because they're better steaks out there at steakhouses. Then we finished with a chocolate ganach. Fire in the sky is a must have cocktail very delicious and it's not too spicy. The food is 5 stars and the service was also perfect. The only thing not so great is the space and the decor for a Michelin one star restaurant. Our table was wobbly and people kept butting on our table when they want to get out to go to the bathroom. The bathroom is also very dark. I think if the vibe improves a little in this restaurant then it would be amazing!!!

The food at Tuome is very good and probably deserving of a Michelin star given the excellent presentation and freshness of each dish. We ordered several dishes including the delicious deviled eggs which are to die for. We were a bit let down by the main course steak dish - it seems like ordering a bunch of apps and sides + the pig feast is the way to go.

Been here three times and each time they have "run out" of the menu that brought us there. The first two times we got something else like the "pig out" Berkshire pork (too salty) or snow crab noodle (very good). The last time we decided not to eat and walked out. They tend to overbook and they obviously don't buy enough food so the patron can actually get get what they want. It's just very disappointing when this happens consistently. If it weren't for the fact that we lived a block away we would not have returned after the 2nd time but now we know better. Too bad. Could have been a nice neighborhood gem.

I live nearby Tuome and have been wanting to try it for a while. We had considered going during Restaurant Week but ended up choosing another place. And then lo and behold, Tuome earned its Michelin Star, so we had to come by and try. My boyfriend and I came for dinner on a weekday night around 7:00. We made a reservation day of, but it was definitely bustling by the time we were finishing our meal.  To start, we shared the octopus which may have been my favorite dish of the night. The octopus was crisp and tasty, and the whipped potatoes that came with it were fantastic. Additionally, there was some crispy bacon or chorizo with it that just added additional flavor. For our entree, we had to do the pork belly for two. The peanut noodles were tasty but a little overwhelming after a while. We both didn't finish our noodles although the portions were definitely large. We finished all the pork belly, which was great and came with two sauces as well as an arugula salad. Finally, we shared the curry Mac and cheese as a side. This dish is extremely unique and surprising when you first taste it. We had just come back from a vacation in India, and it was strange to taste the curry with traditional macaroni shells, but it definitely grew on us, and we finished the whole thing.  Overall, we spent about $50 each, which was reasonable for the portions and quality of food we got. My only hesitation was the service was slightly lacking to me in regards to earning a Michelin Star. It was not bad by any means but not great, compared to what you normally see at Michelin starred restaurants. I noticed they offered to take other people's coats, but they did not offer to take mine. They forgot to bring out our Mac and cheese with the entree, and I had to remind the waitress that we still had not gotten it yet. We also noticed at the table next to us that they brought the wrong appetizer to the wrong table. Just nit picky things but my reason for not giving 5 stars. Overall did definitely enjoy the meal though!

Food good but the service is extremely disappointing and definitely not at the level of a one starred Michelin restaurant. Let me give you some examples: waiters are taking away dishes from the table while one of the guests is still eating; I explicitly arranged a birthday candle for my wife and they forgot it. Then, when I told them about it, they didn't do ANYTHING to find a solution, neither a glass of champagne or a second bite of desert. That's really unfortunate; if you're looking for a nice Michelin Star restaurant to spend a romantic and special night, this is NOT the place. If you're looking for a casual restaurant with good food (the chicken liver was great as the duck and the pork) you can give it a try.

Note to management: No one in your restaurant should feel uncomfortably cold while having dinner. The cold draft in your tables by the windows is a big problem that should be addressed. Unfortunately this affected our experience.

Dinner started well, we ordered two starters, devil eggs and octopus, both were delicious. Then we ordered the signature main, Pig Out. We couldn't finish the dish because it was way way way  too greasy. The crispy part of the pork is soaked in oil. I think it's fried rather than roasted. I normally love fried food, but this is too much. On top of it, the noodles served with the dish were overloaded with sweet peanut sauce, there is no flavor other than sweetness. If you want dessert while having your entre, then this might have been a good choice. Service is good overall.

I had a fantastic meal at Tuome and they recently also just gained one Michelin star for NY!! From the food, service to the ambiance, everything was just perfect for a night out with 3 of my best friends! We ordered a variety of dishes to share as each portion was on the smaller side. Do note that their dishes are rich so you do get full easily (at least for us). Deviled Eggs - WOW, this has got to be my favorite and best deviled eggs I have ever eaten...Absolutely amazing. The egg white was lightly fried to perfection and the yolk and toppings were absolutely divine! I especially liked the addition of xo chili sauce to top it off. Chicken Liver Mouse - another amazing dish. So cream, so flavorful and delicious. Another must get here! Snow crab noodles - wow another to die for dish. The noodles are al dente.. covered in this creamy dashi butter sauce topped with snow crab. It was so delicious, we couldn't stop eating it. Unlike anything I tasted before! Beef - (not sure what cut this was), but it was tender as F! It was so good, flavored well and also gluten free! Loved the sweet savory sauce that the meat was cooked in. Pig out for two (came with peanut noodles) - This dish was good, but I expected a little more since most yelpers hyped this dish up. The skin was extra crispy which I liked, but the overall pork meat it self was mediocre. I say that because I've literally had multiple versions of this dish and I personally prefer the meat to be a full piece and not fall apart. I didn't get that texture of the pork and I couldn't pick up the full with chopsticks either. Overall, a great restaurant and would try again!

Well-deserved Michelin star. Ordering one of the interesting original cocktails is a must. The Pig Out (pork belly dish) is done very well. There's a lot of attention to detail with the flavors and it pays off.All that said, there were a few small downsides. The layout is very packed, so when the restaurant is full the ambiance can suffer a little bit. We were served some sort of curry-flavored popcorn before the meal. Although a little creative, it was a bit underwhelming. The popcorn didn't seem to fit the original and intricate culinary approach.Overall though, it's a fantastic experience and it will be exciting to see the ways this restaurant continues to grow.

Definitely wouldn't mind coming back here. My friends and I love to try different pasta dishes anywhere so we came here for the crab noodle. We did the pre-fixe menu ($48 for appetizer, main dish and dessert. We also ordered the Fluke and a side of Mac and cheese. For drinks we got the Sangria (soooo delicious) Honestly, everything was amazing. The best part was the freshness of those beignets!!! You can't convince me they aren't kneading that dough in the back themselves, lol. Our waitress was also very knowledgeable of the menu and helped with suggestions. Will certainly be going back some time.

One of the most delicious meals I've had in NY. Came here on thanksgiving eve, and was able to make last minute reservations on OpenTable for seating at the bar. Resy had table reservations open, but charged a $5 fee per person for these last minute reservations.  When we arrived, the restaurant was full despite it being the night before a holiday. I ordered off the prix fixe menu, while my boyfriend, a vegetarian, ordered the single vegetarian main entree. Service was friendly but it took some time for each dish to come out. Luckily, each dish was incredibly delicious. We started with the roasted miso blue cheese cauliflower; the sauce was rich with umami flavors and the blue cheese was never overpowering. We are every bit of this and used our utensils to spoon up the rest of the sauce. Next, my snow crab noodles came and his mushroom noodle dish. The next day, I spent all of thanksgiving dinner talking about how good this dish was. The noodles were so buttery and lightly sweet and perfectly chewy. I made plans to come back immediately with my family so I could eat this again. Last a DIY ice cream sandwich came out with fried mantou buns, ice cream, caramel, fruit preserve. We finished it easily. All ice cream sandwiches should be made with fried mantou buns.

Had a really great experience at Tuome. Food: A-; Service: A+; Atmosphere: A- Food: A-1) Cauliflower: Huge piece of cauliflower!! The blue cheese miso really elevated the dish. Really creamy.2) Chicken liver: Really fun dish! The chicken liver mousse was topped with a dollop of maple syrup, which blended perfectly with the savory mousse. Meant to be eaten on little pieces of toast, and topped with kosher salt, pumpkin (?) seeds, and sprouts which you add on yourself.3) Snow crab: Was a very decadent dish. Basically a creamy seafood pasta. Flavor was great. Good amount of crab.4) Chicken: The chicken was on a bed of congee that was topped with a mild sweet soy sauce. 5) Pig out for 2: Really decadent dish. Reminiscent of Chinese roast pig with the crispy skin, but more moist and greasy. Came with spicy peanut noodles that I wasn't able to try because of allergies. Friends were fans of it though.6) Broccoli: Really well flavored, but after a few bites felt a little too greasy.7) Rice: The rice was like the sticky rice wrapped in a lotus leaf that you can find at dim sum restaurants! The flavor was delicious because of the duck fat and the kale went surprisingly well, but wish it had a little more meat in it!8) Beignet: Probably the most disappointing dish of the night. Just four pieces of fried bread served with caramel sauce and a side of vanilla ice cream. Wasn't bad, but lacked the innovation and more complex flavor profiles that the other dishes had.- Service: A+Our waitress was SUPER sweet and really attentive. She was really diligent about the peanut allergy I had, and always made sure our water glasses were refilled, etc.- Atmosphere: AReally intimate and homey. The restaurant is small and dimly lit, which makes it feel cozy, especially during a winter night.

Hands down best pork belly I have ever eaten.  Crispy skin and moist on the inside. Accompanied by peanut noodles - also excellent - perfectly aldente with a rich and well-balanced sauce. Definitely want to come back.

Wow the food is incredible. I love this place. In general, I don't like any fusion food. But this place is amazing.Sangria here is mind blowing. I highly recommend it. I've never had any cocktail like it. The free curry flavored popcorn is great.For appetizers, we got quail and deviled eggs. Both were awesome. The reinvented food with Chinese sauce and flavors was very delicious and innovative. For main course, we got Pig Out. Almost everyone in the restaurant got the same. It was excellent. The pig was roasted perfectly. The sauce was a great compliment. Lychee salad was a nice surprise. It came with sesame noodles. The noodles were more like authentic Chinese noodles actually.The restaurant was nicely decorated and the dining environment was great. Service was solid. I really liked the restaurant. Also this is a new Michelin one star restaurant this year.

Had a stellar meal with two girlfriends on a weekend evening. We had an 8pm reservation, and the restaurant was just over half full, but by the time we left, it was packed. The menu and waitstaff are a little pretentious, but the food is unique and great to share. Portions are on the smaller side. For the three of us who were not starving, we split two "appts," 1 entree, and a side. We probably could have done with one more dish.We started with the cauliflower with blue cheese miso. Interesting flavor combination and presentation. The octopus was very pretty and tasty, as well, though I had recently had another awesome octopus at Suprema Provisions, and this one was probably a notch below it. Our one main, the snow crab, was rich but light at the same time; each bite really melted in my mouth. But the standout to me that I keep talking about is the mac and cheese, which had karee curry. What an awesome idea!Definitely a unique concept. A little pricey, but if you want to impress someone, this spot is a good option.
This place is fantastic. Couldn't believe I was fortunate to stumble upon it on a random Friday night. Legit one of the best restaurant experiences I've had in the city. Food was top notch
So so so good! Easily one of the best meals I've had this year! Everything we tried was delicious - I can't imagine you could go wrong with anything on the menu.

Broccoli - off the hook w a nice savory sauce bathing them green goodies topped with some spicy Sichuan flakes. Not hot but just a little heat for flavor.Scallops - perfectly cooked w nice creamy saucePig Out for two - new age American spin to classic Chinese crispy pork dish. Still kept the super crispy and airy fried skin but the meat has been ground to a fine grade creates an interesting dichotomy of textures. I liked but didn't love it. Came here w my pops to check out a Chinese American chef doing work. Chef Tommy Chen came out to say wassup and that made my pops smile. That alone gives this joint full marks. He's super nice and gave me some dope advice for my Chef BiL. Humble and chill - plus tall dude, wanna hoop w him.

Punchline: Food was great, service was terrible.Had a reservation for 5 for 9pm on a Saturday night.  Tuome has a cozy, relaxed ambiance - the space is ideal for smaller groups.  A short while after ordering, 2 of our 3 appetizers came out.  It took another 15 minutes for the third appetizer to appear.  Aside from the wait, the food tasted wonderful.  The Cauliflower was by far the best, although the fluke crudo was great as well.After the appetizers, there was a long wait for our entrees, the first did not come out until 1hr40min into our meal.  To make matters worse, only 1 of the entrees was served.  Our waitress did not say anything about the others, just went back behind the bar to polish some wine glasses.  I had to flag down a manager to ask about the rest of the food.  After 10 minutes, the rest of the food was served.  Again, everything tasted very good, but the waiting and uneven service was very poor.  From looking around the restaurant throughout the night, we could tell we were not the only table waiting long periods of time for food.  After our entrees, we did not ask for a dessert menu, we had waited long enough.

This was an awesome Tasting Collective dining club event we attended. It was 8-course East Meets West Feast. The inside was small, but cozy and welcoming. The décor was mix of sleek, modern fixtures and reminiscence of the past with the red brick wall throughout the space. I liked the pop of red here and there. They had a small bar with a handful of tables, and then another smaller room to the left with more tables.At this event, we were able to try Watermelon & Ricotta, Chicken Liver Mousse, Crispy Deviled Egg, Fried Chicken, Shrimp On Chip, Snow Crab, Lamb Shank, and Beignet Ice Cream Sandwich. We enjoyed every dish, especially The Crispy Deviled Egg and Fried Chicken. The Deviled Egg was very interesting and tasty, I have never had a deviled egg like the one they have. Very unique and creative! The Fried Chicken was amazing, crispy and juicy, packed with flavor! We also ordered a cocktail, The Blushing Dragon Sangria. It was not sweet, nor strong. The small ice cubes kind of watered down the drink. It didn't really have much of lychee flavor that I was looking for, which was disappointing.We had a really nice dinner, everything was tasty from the beginning to the end. I would love to go back to taste other innovative dishes, but will stick with the food and not the drink...

First time trying a chinese/american fusion, it's super good. We tried the pre fix menu ($45 per person), chicken liver mousse (appetizer) + snow crab noodle (main) + fried mantou (dessert). Can't wait to go back and try Pig Out!Definitely a 5 star!

Came here for dinner last night for restaurant week. We had a reservation, but still had to wait 5-10 minutes to be seated. Complimentary (and pretty tasty) popcorn was provided after we ordered. I chose the chicken liver for my appetizer, the snow crab for my entree, and the beignet ice cream sandwich for my dessert. The chicken liver was delicious and was my favorite part of the meal. It was so creamy, smooth, and buttery, but still had that animal liver taste that people who like liver enjoy. It also came with a sweet syrup, which I thought paired really well with the chicken liver, even though I don't typically like mixing sweet with savory. There were six small slices of bread and my only complaint was that there wasn't enough bread compared to the liver! I only enjoyed about half of the snow crab entree. It got pretty heavy after 10 minutes, but the crab itself was really good and I loved the crunchy texture of the noodles. The beignet ice cream sandwich for dessert was my least favorite part of the meal. The ice cream wasn't anything special and the beignet was quite oily.4/5 experience overall. Appreciated the Asian fusion dishes and I thought most items were prepared well. Taste | 4Atmosphere | 4Presentation | 4Service | 4OVERALL | 4

I only Yelp if I'm blown away, either in disgust or in awe. OMG TUOME! Everything we had was HEAVENLY. I couldn't find one flaw in anything. The service was great, they had the manners/etiquette of an upscale restaurant but without the attitude or stiffness. The food was just out of this world. Our favorites were the chicken liver mousse, snow crab noodles and the chicken cooked two ways with the porridge. I can't decide what was best, but they were all in the top tastiest foods I've ever had. It's not an inexpensive place but the food is beyond worth it. I've had much more expensive food and it was no where near as good. Such a gem in the East Village! We will be back again and again!!

The plates look small but very rich very fulfilling. Definitely try the octopus with the house special sauce (creamy, foamy and yummy!) In general the food was nice. Not giving 5 stars because I think it's a little overpriced (e.g. the pig out thing is not worth $56....)

Two words...PIG OUT!  Literally, pig out on their dish "Pig Out." I came here for restaurant week and I have been waiting months to come back to this restaurant again!  The first time I tried to get a seat, the wait was too long so I didn't have a chance to try it....this time, I planned ahead and made a reservation.  Food: - HEIRLOOM TOMATO - [RICOTTA, VADOUVAN GRANOLA, BASIL] - This dish was very refreshing.  Tasty, but nothing amazing.  Only ordered this because it sounded better than the 3rd option. - CHICKEN LIVER - [MOUSSE, NY MAPLE, MILK BREAD] - Now, I usually do not like liver because of that iron taste, but this dish was really delicious!  I actually asked my friend to make me a second toast and then we asked for more bed to finish the mousse off!  Definitely try this dish if you have a chance.  - QUAIL - [CLASSIC SOY SAUCE, SMOKED POTATO, MIZUNA] - super tender little bird with a nice reduced soy sauce.  What was best about this dish was that the flavor brought back childhood memories of my grandma's cooking!  That was the best part.  Another dish highly recommended! - PIG OUT (FOR TWO) - [BERKSHIRE PORK, SPICY PEANUT NOODLE, CONDIMENTS] - So this was actually the highlight of the night.  Apparently it takes 3 days to cook this pork.  It has a really nice crisp skin topping.  The pork is shredded and made into a block.  It's paired with grated ginger, hot sauce, and peanut noodles.  Pork is a little big salty, but not unbearable and pairs well with the noodles.  Noodles are cooked al dente and the peanut sauce is very flavorful.  This is a must have if you come eat at Tuome.  Very unique dish that I haven't had anywhere else.  - TAPIOCA - [COCONUT PUDDING, BERRIES, ALMOND] - standard tapioca pudding, nothing special.  - BEIGNET - [ICE CREAM SANDWICH, GOAT'S MILK CARAMEL] - this was pretty good.  It was like a fried bao, crispy and slightly warm and paired with the ice cream.  A little too much breading for me so I just ate one side with the ice cream. Service was great and they explained a lot of the dishes very well.  Glad I got a chance to dine here and I will definitely be coming back to try the other dishes on the menu, and maybe even the pork if I come with a larger party of people.

Tuome is a American restaurant with a Chinese twist in the East Village/ Alphabet City. The food was of higher caliber than your usual fusion restaurant, the service was good (they were short that night) and the ambience was charming and simple (think dimly-lit barely-on Edison bulbs, candles, and dark wooden chairs and tables).We went for our friends' joint birthday dinner. The night was humid and the flash flooding turned some roads into mini river ways. Stepping in the dim restaurant, it took a few seconds for my eyes to adjust and find my party. I was glad to be inside a cool dry restaurant. It happened to be restaurant week; the pricing was similar to Tuome's usual prix fixe and restaurant week's menu gave us slightly more options so we opted for 2018 restaurant week menu.We tried the following:Pig in a blanket- crispy pork cutlet with pickled daikon, capers, and shishito. This was ok. It was a decent crispy pork sandwich.Heirloom tomatoes salad with ricotta, basil and granola- I liked the granola mixed in. It was appetizing and simple. Chicken liver mousse with maple and milk bread- This was the best appetizer out of the three options. The liver was creamy, sweet and very rich. It was magical. I wish I had ordered this dish. Pig out for two- It came in ~ 2 cm x 2 cm cubes with a total of 10 cubes. They looked the traditional Cantonese roast pork but the cubes were made of braised juicy pork compressed into cubes with a tiny square of broiled crunchy pork crackling. It was delicious. It was like a great version of the Chinese roasted pork since this version had perfectly crispy crackling AND juicy pork underneath. Usually the pork is a little dry in the Chinatown version. I enjoyed it. I also love the Chinatown version.Peanut noodles- the noodles were egg noodles al dente with creamy sweet peanut sauce. It was topped with crispy onions. This was really fun to eat.Snow crab noodle- creamy noodles in dashi butter and topped with snow crab meat. The crab meat was delicate tender chunks of snow crab with the rich umami noodles. This was my favorite noodle dish of the night. Rice- this was sticky rice with kale, Chinese sausage and duck fat wrapped in bamboo leaf. This was wonderfully familiar of the zhongzhi of my youth. My grandma used to wrap zhongzhi filled with tiny shrimps, shiitake mushrooms and peanuts. She would lovingly fold in chunks of pork fat to flavor the sticky rice.This version of zhongzhi looked the same with mildly sweet sticky rice in the bamboo leaf. The kale and duck fat were a welcome twist on a classic. The duck fat was aromatic and added a savory butteriness. The kale was softened and tasted sautéed with garlic. I'm not sure my grandma would approve but I really enjoyed the nod to the past and innovative touches. Mac and Cheese- this was good. Creamy pasta shells with curry, parmesan and chives. There was a unique kick to the mac and cheese, which tasted like 5 spices. It was unique and ok.  Dessert:Beignet- this was a crunchy shell with vanilla ice cream. It was ok. I would return for the Pig out, the rice and snow crab noodle. Dessert you can get elsewhere.instagram.com/snackchatn…

We had a delicious dinner for two for Restaurant Week (Summer 2018). It totaled to $42 each for a three course meal. We also ordered drinks - Fire in the Sky ($13) and Blushing Sangria ($13). I'd recommend the FITS over the sangria. For food, we ordered the tonkatsu and the chicken pate for our appetizers followed by the snow crab pasta and chicken porridge for our entrees and ending with ice cream and pudding for dessert. The food was pretty good. My favorites were the pate and the crab pasta by far. The tonkatsu was dry, porridge and ice cream were fine, pudding is very heavy in lactose so be forewarned. Based on the meal, I would've given four stars because the pate and pasta were stellar. But, what made me dock a star and never want to come back is that I was overcharged $3.77 on my total bill, despite giving a fairly standard 18% tip. Now, am I mad at the extra $3.77 - no, I am not - but THIS. IS. STEALING. I don't know how often this happens, but this is morally and legally wrong.

Came back 3 more times this past month. Found out you don't need to wait for restaurant week to get a good deal here. From Monday-Thursday they have the same restaurant week price during those days!! Tuome needs to win like the Nobel Peace Prize. Cuz Tuome always creates peace in my life after I have a few bites of their food. Just simply amazing.Tried the Pig out for Two finally...had to convince my bf to stop getting the crab noodles so we can both try the pig. OUT OF THIS WORLD. My two favorite things- crispy pork combined with peanut butter noods. Life just doesn't get better than this. Other must gets- the Octopus. Perfectly cooked and the brown butter & potato puree and sprinkle of Chinese sausage is insane.

Came here during restaurant week. I ordered the set, and my bf ordered an entree so that while we both have our own entrees, we can share appetizer and dessert.Food we've got:Free popcorn: the seasoning is some curry powder and lemongrass; full of flavor, pretty good, but I still love the free popcorn in distilled a tad moreChicken liver: my favorite dish of the night! The bread pieces came warm and crispy, while chicken liver was so smooth. Finished it in matter of minutesSnow crab pasta: good, but nothing spectacular. The noodle is creamy and has a small portion of snow crab meat on top. However, there is not much interaction between the flavors of the crab and the noodles, and the portion of snow crab is really small. So I would not really recommend it.Scallop: scallop tastes good: chewy and flavorful, but the dish is simply three scallops+ few corns, so it did not fill my bf up at all.Coconut rice pudding: another good but nothing spectacular dish. The portion is also very small- we finished it in three spoons.In all, if you ever plan to come, be aware of the small portion of dishes! Also, the restaurant is tiny with little room between tables. Other than that, the food is pretty unique.

Amazing find for Restaurant Week! Never would have found this little gem in Alphabet City if it weren't for my favorite summer foodie holiday. The snow crab noodles with dashi butter was really the star of the show - super rich and buttery, delicate crab meat, a touch of freshness with the chives on top - definitely order these noodles!The service was a little slow, but the place was decently full for a Friday night. I'm not sure if the regular menu prices are worth what you get, but there again lies the value of Restaurant Week :) Overall, a great date night pick!

I came here for restaurant week with my wife.  We enjoyed the ambiance as it is very romantic type of lighting and feeling.  The tables are a little close to each other, but I guess that is something you probably deal with in most NY restaurants.  The food was exceptional and it was great way to get to know the restaurant during NYC restaurant week.

Due to my sadly limited bank account (sup ladies! #imsingle), this is the first WOAH restaurant that I've eaten at in quite a while. Friends who use their expense accounts to pay for meals at expensive restaurants are THE BEST FRIENDS. Keep them at your side.Anywho, the service was quite low-key but very good at. The place doesn't seat too many people (20-30). There's only one unisex, cramped bathroom. A couple apps, two entrees, two cocktails, a side, tax, and tip came out to $140.So now that we've gotten the boring stuff out of the way, onto the food.It was phenomenal. I'm not a skilled food writer, nor I do pretend to be. So I'll simply list everything that my manfriend and I ordered. It was all spectacular and I would highly recommend ordering all of it.Pre-Appz:Free popcorn, yummyAppz:EGG - [DEVILED, CRISPY, CHILI] 8  (remarkable)FLUKE - [CRUDO, COCONUT VINAIGRETTE, BLACK SESAME CRISP] 15 (such a gorgeous texture)Entrees:STRIPED BASS - [BLACK LENTIL, BONITO, ENGLISH PEAS] 29 BEEF - [POTATO ROSTI, SHALLOT, CORN] 33 (very filling)Sides:MAC & CHEESE - [KAREE CURRY, PARMESAN, AND CHIVES] 11 (quite good)I believe that they had only one dessert option, beignets (definitely had to Google how to spell that). Neither Mr. Moneybags or I found that particularly appealing, so we headed somewhere else for dessert. Perhaps they don't care much about dessert. It's not even a part of their menu.Anywho. Go here. You'll love it. Here's the NY Times 2014, 2-star ("very good") review: nytimes.com/2014/11/05/d…

Cute place, but nothing to write home about. Definitely a lot of better restaurants in the n'hood.  I had the snow crab and I thought it was just okay - not like how others are raving about it. Way too heavy for my taste. But again, cute place, would come for happy hour, but wouldn't come back for dinner.

Tuome isn't a restaurant as much as it's a place to hang out with friends or bring a date who you don't really care about. There isn't much to distinguish this place from any other gastropub, but Tuome I feel has bought into it's own hype. The stylistic food and subtle tastes does little to make one remember or even want to come back. We were a group of three, saw the place on facebook post, great free advertising, but as we all know everyone on social media lies right? Started with the chicken liver, and the four slices of milk bread that it came with. Great pate, but 4 pieces of one slice of white bread,? really? really? I already knew I was going to be hungry after eating in this place. Had the quail, meh, the finer intricacies elude me after what amounted to eating a hummingbird. Octopus, a slight improvement in taste, still a common flavor profile exists of texture, flavor, counter flavor. Subtle tones of countryside fare?; maybe with enough wine it might taste better? Then had the scallops which were memorable, if only that flavor memory didn't last four bites? Pig out for two was what brought me to the place, so tried it, crunchy, hearty, not a lot of oil, then paired with the peanut noodle absolutely confused my taste buds. The protein was savory, less filing than I'd hoped, but not entirely original, maybe a little bit more chic. Ok so bottom line this place is for people that hate food, folks who just want to be seen eating great food, or people who just wish to overpay for something while sucking down bottles of wine. Come to Tuome for wine, for laughs, for discussions about art and whatever gives your lives meaning but don't come for the food, because there's nothing here that you'll remember, and you'll still be hungry when you leave. Maybe thats what you're looking for who knows. Thanks for your time.

Yes, it is pricey. You're in NYC and you want to dine out at a place that serves really amazing food. You shouldn't be so surprised to pay a little. We had the pig out, broccoli, octopus and snow crab pasta. Between the 3 of us, that was enough food. We were full but didn't get a food coma...so that's a good feeling.If you love octopus, you must get it here. The texture of octopus is 1000% the bestest ever. So soft & subtle with flavors... Then there's aerated mashed potato (!!!) to accompany said amazing octopus. One of the best, if not the best, octopus I've ever had.Lastly, the gold medal goes to (I know, octopus didn't take it) the snow crab pasta. I didn't get a chance to analyze it too much because I slurped it down so fast wanting for more with every bite. I will be back just to eat this dish again. With that said, I can't describe how delicious this dish really is - you must try it for yourself.

Really cool and delicious place by Avenue B. The fried chicken sliders were moist and a little sweet. The chicken liver mouse was so smooth and the maple syrup on top of if worked so well. For the main course we had the snow crab pasta. The noodles were cooked really well and had a great texture to them. Additionally, the daikon butter sauce added so much flavor to the dish. I'll definitely go back.

Boutique shop... courageous idea... Chinese American cuisine!!!See here is the thing with Chinese cuisine. It can range from a mom and pop shop serving the general Tso chicken and fries crab wonton, to high end traditional highly skilled technique dishes; it can be very easy to make Chinese food, but at the same time very easy to screw it up.  The problem with Tuome is that they are right in the middle of that scale.If you never had Chinese food, then Tuome is a good place for you to start. If have Chinese food pretty much throughout your whole life, the. It might be a bit disappointing, which is exactly my case.My wife and I came here on my birthday night. The mocktail and my ale beer is really refreshing pairing with the chicken pate and crispy toast. I would say that is my favorite.The big out (for 2) was a dish I have always wanted to try after watching a YouTube review. My problem with this dish is that the technique is overly complicated. Basically the chef deconstructed the pork belly by pulling the meat out from the pork skin, then put them back together using duck fat to confit the pork meat. To be honest, there is not much of flavor there but a mouthful of duck grease... not at all what I expected.The rice side dish is not bad, but cannot be considered to be delicious. If you have been to dim sum place, the rice with Chinese sausage is way better tasting. I know it might not be fair to compare Chinese American cuisine to traditional Chinese, but when they are making their dishes so similar to the traditional version but lacked the deliciousness and flavor, then it might better just go totally wild to reinvent a traditional dish instead of playing safe. A 3 star is given for their service, ambiance, and the "ok" food.
Absolutely fantastic. Food was exciting but well portioned, flavors were amazing, and the staff was so kind and helpful. Would go back!

Gorgeous well run establishment. Amazing food. Amazing servers. The peanut noodles are to die for. This is a must for any food connoisseur - and the positive reviews keep stacking up thanks to word of mouth.

Friday night made a reservation for seven and it was pretty empty when we arrived but boy does it fill up fast. The place is cozy and really liked the overall vibe. All the staff were super nice and made sure we felt taken care of. Five stars for service! We started out with the deviled eggs which were amazingggg deep fried with some asian touches. I was impressed. With the pig out - not so much. I didn't really care for the meat and the noodles were too peanuty and undercooked? It was just okay. Overrated I think. They do have one dessert each night, which is not on the menu. For us it was chinese donut with vanilla ice cream, citrus, red bean and caramel. How can you go wrong with donut and ice cream? You can't. I'll probably be back to try the snow crab noodles though and whatever they have for dessert!

I only popped in here for a few Happy Hour drinks with my friend, but I really liked this place overall. It's a small space and dimly lit but the staff is really friendly and (dare I say it) easy on the eyes...We got a little hungry so we ordered the fried chicken sandwich appetizer. It came with two, so easily shareable between two people or, if you're feeling yourself, I guess you can eat both. I really liked the honey plus the daikon relish - it was a nice combination.

The food is incredible here!! My favorites are the deviled eggs and chicken liver for appetizers, and the chicken (w/ gem lettuce, basil and porridge) and snow crab (noodle, squash, dashi butter) for entrees. Beignets are great but wish there were more dessert options!
Really great spot! A huge fan of the Striped Bass. The lentils pair perfectly with the fish. Also highly recommend the potato side. Great service, food, and ambience.

Great flavors. Wouldn't say it's Chinese per se but there's definitely some Asian influence in the flavors. Really liked the chicken liver pâté with milk bread. The duck- a new item on the menu, was also really wonderful. Enjoy their food in an intimate and dim lit ambiance:) it's definitely worth a trip. Make reservations.

Ordered pig out for two was beyond my expectations! We ordered fish for appetizer, and potatoes for sides, and everything was very delicious. Also the server was friendly and welcoming:) loved this place!

At least based on our menu selections at dinner the other day, I really would call this place vaguely Chinese at most. Our meal included some very non-Chinese sounding items including deviled eggs, fried chicken sliders on brioche, chicken liver mousse, and striped bass. There were some Asian flavor touches here and there, like the black sesame crisp on the fluke crudo and the amazing broccoli with Sichuan chili, as well as the sticky rice with Chinese sausage. I also had a wonderfully spicy sake cocktail with yuzu and Thai chili called Fire In The Sky... but that's more Thai/Japanese than Chinese, right?But enough about categories. Tuome was categorically tasty so that's all that matters! My favorites were the broccoli, the deviled eggs (turns out when you deep fry something it's usually pretty tasty), and the fried chicken (turns out, a bun is much more tasty when it's absolutely slathered with butter). Though the server was slow with a few things here and there, she was very friendly and was also understanding when we had a late addition to our table. During the meal I was sure that we'd be spending a ton of money, but after two bottles of wine, some other drinks, and lots and lots of plates to share, we were out of there at about $65/person before tip. Not that bad! I also saw that they have a $45/person tasting menu. The space is dim, romantic, trendy, etc, etc... lots of couples dining with quiet conversation on a Saturday night. The manager/owner, not sure which, was very helpful in suggesting another spot in the neighborhood with great cocktails to continue the evening. It's a little fancier than I would choose to go on any old evening, but it was a lovely experience and on my list to recommend to friends for date nights or special occasion meals in the future.
Favorite restaurant in NYC!  Staff is lovely and food is always delicious.  Been here a dozen times and its amazing every time.
This is really good for people who like to try new things or you like to eat meat I would recommend to try the fried chicken,chicken,and the pig out.

Prices: Pig Out for two $56Deviled Egg appetizer $8I still don't know how you pronounce this place's name, but I enjoyed my dinner here. I made a dinner reservation for two for a Monday night. I probably didn't need to as there were plenty of empty tables when we rolled in for our 8PM reservation. I'm not sure how busy this place gets on the weekend though. If you come here on a Monday to Thursday, you have the option of getting their 3 course prix fixe for $45. It's a pretty good deal given that a single entree already runs around $30. We started with the deviled eggs as an appetizer. It was easily the best deviled egg I've had. They somehow managed to place a delightfully light but crispy crust over the egg white. The yolk came with a touch of chili oil to tie in the Chinese flavor. I was really torn between ordering the snow crab and the Pig Out, but went with Pig Out in the end as it's their most popular dish. I really wish there was a Pig Out option for one so I could've tried both. The dish comes with a bowl of peanut noodles, 5 pieces of pork for each person, and a salad. The noodles had the perfect texture. They were dense and yet still springy. The peanut sauce coating the noodles was reminiscent of the peanut sauce you get to accompany Vietnamese spring rolls. The pork is prepared as a confit in duck fat. The pork itself was super rich and tender.The meat texture fell apart as if it had been shredded and then reassembled. Somehow it oddly held together well enough for me to pick it up with my chopstick despite how it felt like it was falling apart each time I bit into it. I have no idea how they achieved that. Our meat came with a little bottle of pepper sauce and a little bowl of ginger shallot sauce. The pepper sauce added flavor while only throwing in a hint of heat. In all honesty though, the meat had enough flavor on its own that you can eat it plain if you want. The skin on the pork was incredibly crispy. We've eaten our fair share of crispy pork in various Asian dishes, but my husband proclaimed this as the best iteration he's had of it.  Delicious food, intimate atmosphere, and friendly service. If I was a local, I'd already have my next reservation booked to try the snow crab.

Now normally I don't like paying a lot of money for Chinese food but we decided to try this restaurant after reading all the great reviews. And honestly the meal that I had was simply amazing. AMAZING. I came for dinner two weeks ago and I'm still thinking about it!We started off the night with two appetizers, the octopus and the mushrooms. They were both really tasty and perfectly cooked. The mushrooms were a particular favorite because I love black bean sauce and a good two hour egg. For the main entre, we got the pig for two which comes with about 10 large pieces  of pig and wonderful bowl of sesame noodle. I really liked that the noodle was served warm because sesame noodle can go either way. It went great with the pig and the ginger scallion sauce that comes on the side. I can't wait to go again and I definitely recommend it to all!!

TLDR: dimly lit, intimate restaurant serving new american / asian fusion cuisine; delicious food at a great value during restaurant weekCame here with a friend on the last day of restaurant week winter 2018.
