We had made a reservation for Friday at 8:45pm. The lighting was very limited, giving the place an intimate vibe, with exposed brick walls and wooden tables and chairs. I started with the blushing dragon sangria, which I found to be a little too subtle in flavor / watered down. We were also served complimentary popcorn, which was seasoned with cajun spices.For dinner, our server recommended that we order different things to allow us to try almost everything on the menu, which turned out to be a great decision, as everything was flavorful and delicious.Shrimp: served on a toasted tortilla-like chip with crème fraiche and "everything" spice; relatively light with a good balance of refreshing and smokyFried Chicken: on brioche with general tuome's honey and daikon relish; basically fried chicken sliders with tons of flavor; the addition of the relish made it less heavy; one of my favoritesSnow Crab: noodles, squash, dashi butter; noodles were cooked well with a delicious, buttery finish; a little light on the snow crabChicken: gem lettuce, basil, porridge; generous portion size with chicken cooked two ways--fried and baked; chicken was moist and the porridge was very savory; favorite entreeBeignet: ice cream sandwich, goat's milk caramel; light and fluffy shell; sweet, creamy fillingChocolate: tart, mascarpone, almond; didn't try this one due to my nut allergy, but my friend enjoyed itOverall, a great option for restaurant week with flavorful, unique dishes.

This is a small hole in the wall in east village/ alphabet city? We found this place via social media from probably an insider video about their "pig out" meal. Needless so say we were pretty excited to try it. Came on a Tuesday night, it was pretty empty and service was great. They were attentive and explained every dish that came out as well as answered any question that we had.We started with the fried chicken appetizer, which essentially are two fried chicken sliders with a honey sauce and pieces of daikon. LOVED this!! Can they make a bigger version for half the price? They're small.. but so flavorful and juicy.We also had a side of Brussels sprouts, really enjoyed this as well! The grapes gave it a good balance of flavor. The Berkshire pork which I guess is supposed to be the highlight of the pig out, to be honest fell short. It was oily, the skin was super crispy, and it all just sounds amazing, but sadly this was disappointing. Even with the condiments on the side, it was just okay. I thought it did lacked some flavor, I did really enjoy the arugula and persimmon on the side though. The peanut noodles that it came with was awesome. Great balance of Szechuan spice and peanut flavor. The noodles were the right texture, not soggy at all. Al dente is the word I guess.

We all know this place is know for the pig out which wont disappoint but do yourself a favor and get the deviled eggs to start , they just took them to another level.Great food and cute place but please Tuome turn up the heating it was freezing the night i was there !

Went there during NYC Restaurant Week.  We ordered the followings -Beets salad - it was not bad, very colorfulFried Chicken - It was okayPig Out For Two - Total disappointment; the skin was so hard, I think the meat would taste better without the "crispy" skinSide order - Rice; my husband and I were shocked!  it's pretty much sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaf.  Even the frozen ones we get from the store would taste better. Not to mention, the sticky rice was $9!Desserts - Beignet; was pretty good, enjoyed the fried dough with ice cream; didn't like the chocolate.I think this place is way overpriced and the food was not that good.  Good service though.

Went here with a couple of friends on a Friday night. I was sure to make a reservation and we were able to be seated right away.We were all pretty hungry, so we decided to split a few dishes:Egg (3.5 stars): These were good, but seemed to be a little less exciting than was expected based on all the ingredients and special preparation.Snow crab (5 stars): Oh. My. Gawd. This. Dish. I don't even know where to begin. I did not even know that I enjoyed snow crab until I had this dish. The crab was so tender and flavorful and paired perfectly with the noodles. This was definitely the best dish of the night.Pig out (4 stars): This was the dish that I expected to shine most. The peanut noodles were definitely 5 stars, but the pork belly was closer to 3 stars as it was overcooked and almost too crunchy to eat. The sauces that it was served with were nice, but they couldn't make up for the lack of tenderness.Rice (5 stars): This is one of the best rice dishes I have ever had. Totally was not expecting the dish to be so tasty and was definitely the most bang for the buck dish of the night.Brussels Sprout (4.5 stars): These were done well--a mostly classic preparation with a few additions that really elevated the dish.Overall, the food here was spectacular and that was despite the underwhelming pork belly that we expected to be the bright spot of the meal. In addition, the service was top notch and super friendly as they let us enjoy a leisurely meal that definitely topped the 3 hour mark. The main downside of this place is that the pricing is a bit absurd as some of the dishes (especially the pig out) are very overpriced. That being said, the quality is worth biting the bullet for a special occasion.

Service left more to be desired. Food was tasty. Overall would recommend trying it out, although it's far from being my favorite "creative" / "hip" fusion Chinese restaurant.Had an 8:45pm reservation for a party of four on Lunar New Year's Eve. We weren't seated until close to 9:20pm. A friendly host checked in on us intermittently to provide timing updates, but the fact of the matter was that we were not seated until 30 minutes after our reservation time.The waitress was friendly, although there was a period of time towards the latter half of our meal where our water glasses were empty for 20 minutes, and I was really thirsty given how salty one of the dishes was. I wouldn't have minded if it weren't for the fact that there were only a few tables left at the time, so the service could have been more attentive.We ordered the shrimp on chip appetizer, chicken liver with milk bread appetizer, crab noodles with dashi butter, spicy peanut sauce noodles, side of sticky rice, berkshire pork for two, and the chicken two ways with porridge. The shrimp was my least favorite. It didn't taste bad, but the flavors of the shrimp, the chip, seasonings, and creme fraiche did not pair well together. I enjoyed the chicken liver and they gave us extra bread too. Very delicious and would recommend this as a starter dish. The crab noodles had potential to be my favorite dish of the night - I love buttered noodles with seafood. However, this dish came out WAY too salty to enjoy! Same with the spicy peanut noodles. The berkshire pork for two dish was tasty - the meat melted in your mouth, but the portion size is barely made for two. The chicken was my favorite of the night. The dark meat was very flavorful and rich. The breast was cooked sous-vide and not overly dry, and I really enjoyed the "risotto-like" base that accompanied the chicken.

Had a lovely dinner there last night with my wife and another couple.  I have not had a meal at a restaurant that was this flawless in a long time.  It's a small space but the tables are not too close.  There's cool 80s music playing, but not so loud that you can't have a conversation.  Can't rave enough about the service.  Our server (a woman, don't know her name) was friendly and seemed to know what we needed before we did.  The food was interesting and in a couple of instances were new interpretations of classics (the fried deviled eggs and beignets come to mind).  We all shared everything and there was not a single misstep with any of the dishes.  Even the wine was great (a sangiovese for forty something dollars a bottle).  All four of us left this little gem last night totally blown away.

The deviled eggs are to die for.  Worth returning just for that dish, which wound up being the highlight of our meal.  The octopus was fair and the pig out had a lovely crunch to it though the noodle accompaniment was a bit much.  We rather enjoyed it with their delicious Brussels sprouts instead.  Shout out to our wonderful waitress Cat.  If you're there on Valentine's Day as well, wish her a happy early birthday.  All in all I'd recommend tuome and look forward to exploring the menu more.

I'm giving one extra star for the great British New Wave soundtrack they were playing.  Food, especially for the prices charged, was really not special.  Chicken Liver appetizer was sickly sweet with the maple syrup and still oversweet when we got a version without it.Mushroom appetizer was quite good. Pig Out was very one note with its crispy pork belly and spicy peanut noodles. Eventually started to leave an aftertaste in one's mouth.  Especially for price charged, not particularly impressive.  Nice location, seems like a good waitstaff, but not a place I would need to revisit.

I went to the place for restaurant week and I couldn't be happier that I did. It's very pricey but well worth it. The food was unbelievable. Going during restaurant week is an amazing deal so hop on it before this season ends and keep an eye out for the next restaurant week. The whole menu was great but the snow crab noodle dish was unlike anything I've ever eaten in my life. Seriously I will be going back purely because that dish was so good. It is so buttery, perfect amount of crab, perfectly cooked fresh noodles. Highly recommend this dish. The atmosphere of the restaurant is super coast and romantic- this would be a really great date spot... low lighting small intimate tables... candle light and a stellar wine list. The restaurant itself is tucked away in the east village and has a permanent spot on my list of favorite places in the neighborhood. Definitely try it!

Ate at barHappy hour cocktails great dealsFried chicken appetizer- chicken was fried wellSnow crab noodles - pretty much lost my appetite when I saw it - server had both thumbs in the inside of my bowl - same guy I watched behind the bar folding napkins, cleaning up the bar, organizing menus. Not cool. Picked off crab, had some noodles - dish was heavy.

The biggest problem with this place is probably prices - everything obscenely priced for what you get.  The snow crab noodles were really good, the Octopus was salty and more crisp than tender - the eggs were fine but as a whole it did not make me want to come back for $52 pork belly for two.

Winter Restaurant Week 2018:Stopped in last Fri for a 9pm reservation and the place was totally packed. Many people waiting awkwardly by the front door. They seemed to have trouble getting people seated on time and were giving out champagne to the patient diners. We were seated 20 mins or so after our reservation time, yet weren't offered anything while others who arrived after us were. Hmm.I haven't been a fan of restaurant week in the past because I don't believe places put forth their best effort to discounted diners. Tuome sort of turned me around. I had wanted to try their snow crab noodles with dashi butter for some time and saw this as a perfect opportunity. I was very happy they had it on the RW menu.I had a "Fire in the Sky" sake cocktail which was SO good. Gingery. I loved it. Followed by a nice IPA.I had the shrimp appetizer while my BF had the fried chicken sliders. The shrimp was unimpressive and bland. As well as a bit difficult to eat. However the fried chicken sliders were incredible. So crunchy and delicious with a sweet sauce and some pickled daikon on top. I could literally have eaten like 10 more. If I ever go back, I will 100% order these again.The much anticipated snow crab noodles totally lived up to the hype. The noodles were perfectly cooked, had just enough bite. The crab was sweet (though scarce) and the dashi butter was rich and profoundly flavorful. I thought the whole thing tasted like a lobster roll, sweet and buttery. They were a bit heavy but it helped you fill up more. The portion was generous. I would go back for these noodles, but no more than once a year because they were swimming in butter.Beignet dessert was not what I expected but I really enjoyed them. The texture was less like a donut and more like a lobster roll Italian pastry. The ice cream and caramel were good. Not too sweet which I definitely appreciate. It was a nice way to end the meal. Overall, I'd love to go back and try more.

Meh, I've experienced better is right. From the dishwater sangria with .0001% alcohol content to the peanut butter noodles my 4 year old could have made, this was one disappointing meal. Nothing was remotely unique, everything was done 10 years ago someplace else and far better...it all lacks pizzazz of any kind. This is one soulless place where the menu descriptions far exceed the actual delivery.What an utter disappointment. Definitely head someplace else if you are looking for a meal that inspires...this place isn't it.
pretty glorious. the pig out is outrageous. the snow crab noodles. amazing mouth feel. def will return. soon.

Tuome is not to be missed. The service was attentive, friendly and efficient. The food was AMAZING! Each dish was progressively better than the one before, with great blends of flavor and texture. Highlights were the Fried Chicken Sliders, the Snow Crab, the Mushrooms and the Octopus.We saved the Pig Out for next time.And there will be many next times!
Truly Fantastic.  'nuff said.  Okay they're saying that review is too short.The chicken with buttered rice? Omg.  Insane.  This food is legit.

SO, SO, SO DELICIOUS! One of the best meals I've had in NYC. We got the octopus as an appetizer, snow crab and bass as main meals, and brussel sprouts as a side. I recommend it ALL!!! We're 100% going to come back!

I made last minute reservations for 5 people on a Tuesday evening @ 8:00PM and it was quick and hassle free. My colleague had been telling me how great this place was, and I was very excited to try it out.The restaurant is on the dimmer, cozier side, and the space itself is not that big. We had the option of doing the $45 weekday prefixe menu (Taste of Tuome) or ordering a la carte off of their regular menu. We opted to do the latter, and were all very pleasantly surprised.Drinks: I ordered the East Village Blossom (refreshingly delicious, not too sweet!) and my friends ordered The Blushing Dragon Sangria and Rare Voss beer. We all ordered the same drinks for our second round, so it's safe to say they were all good.Food: We ordered - Fried Chicken, Chicken Liver, Octopus, Mushroom, Snow Crab, Beef, Pig Out, and a side of Brussels sprouts. Everything was SO GOOD. We all agreed there wasn't a single dish we wouldn't get again. Special shout outs to the Chicken Liver (ask for extra toast!), the Snow Crab (buttery flavored al dente egg noodles topped with snow crab...beautiful marriage), and the Pig Out (juicy Berkshire pork with extra crispy pork with a delicious ginger sauce). Noticing the Asian flair each dish has was fun too. Service: Our server was a young brunette lady and she was quick, friendly, and very knowledgeable. By the end of our meal, we were stuffed and very happy with all that we consumed. The fact that I only live 7 streets away from Tuome is the cherry on top! I'm already excited to return again and try the rest of the items on their fantastic menu.

Made reservations for 7pm on a weekday but you'll probably be fine without at this time as they had open tables, but they did get packed later in the night. The space is dark and cozy. The entrance is spacious and has a bar and a lot of standing space. The room on the left is where most of the dining tables are. There are two large windows turned bench seating and more tables opposite of it.I came here with a friend and we started with cocktails. I got the fire in the sky and my friend got the blushing dragon sangria. We both enjoyed our drinks though I do think hers had a lot of ice in it. We both got the "taste of tuome" which is the 3 course pre-fixe. First, we got the shrimp - the creme fraiche goes really well with the shrimp and the chip adds a nice texture to the mix, but I felt like the shrimp was not flavorful enough even with the spices piled on it. Second, we got the pig out for two - the 10 pieces of pork was super flavorful and the crispy skin on top was cooked to perfection, the side sauces weren't even necessary. It also came with a salad on the side of arugula, persimmons, and walnuts. It also came with bowl of peanut noodles for each of us, which we couldn't finish. The portion looked small, but after eating the pork, it's quite heavy. For dessert we got the beignet (only one option here) where you can build your own little ice cream sandwich. There were four freshly made beignets, ice cream, red bean, goat milk caramel, and citron. I thought the citron was over powering so I avoided that on my second creation.And the service was great!Overall, it was delicious and I'd come back to try the other items.

Tuome is very small and intimating restaurant with warm and cozy interior. I dined on Christmas day at 6:30pm with my partner. Overall, it was pleasant experience but didn't meet my high expectation since Yelp has such high ratings and great reviews from other people. Food itself is above average - flavorful and creative menu items with Chinese influenced. I really appreciate the menu idea. Even though all the menu has very small portion, I have no complaint on that (it's New York).The best menu item I ordered was brussel sprouts. It was well-seasoned, flavorful, and delicious! Most popular menu - Pig Out was Ok though. It's definitely juicy, has wonderful pork flavor but it didn't WOW me unfortunately. Everyone was talking about this pork dish and maybe I was too hyped to try this dish in New York. Restaurant was packed in Christmas day and food service was quite slow. It seemed like everyone ordered Pig Out for entree so my table had to wait quite awhile for the main dish to come out. We sat right next to the entrance, and it was freezing whole evening when people kept coming in. Again, restaurant is really small and there's no space available between your table and group next to you. It was good dining experience, but it didn't blow me away to have me come back in New York. There're just too many other wonderful restaurants to visit.

Fantastic little place in the east village. Really nice cosy feel. Servers are very polite and helpful. Menu is simple and seasonal. Spiced popcorn as a nibble to start us off. I got the prawn starter and Cat got the chicken liver pate - both were great. We got the pork belly for 2 for main course with spicy peanut noodles - fantastic! Reasonably priced with fantastic food. Will definitely return

What a fantastic meal! I've wanted to dine at Tuome for quite some time now but it wasn't until last summer's Restaurant Week did I get to have the chance. And boy have I been missing out! Everything we ate was fantastic! In fact, it was one of the best RW dinners I've had and certainly a most memorable meal of late.For starters, we shared the chicken liver mousse and shrimp tostadas. Both were delightful! The liver mousse was velvety in texture and the combination of the liver and maple syrup was perfect. The tostada was also an interesting dish and certainly piqued my appetite. For the entree we of course had to have the pig out! This is the dish I've so been looking forward to after all. And it was amazing! Perfectly crisp skin and tender pork belly meat along with the condiments, the lychee salad and the peanut noodles.. The entire dish was terrific! Now, the snow crab noodles more than held its own as well. Both my partner and I and our friends all agreed everything was just delicious! The desserts of deconstructed berry tart and the beignet ice cream sandwich were a perfect cap to the meal.I would definitely love to come back again!

Food is super inventive and delish here. No hassle reservation, warm staff, good food at high-er prices but not to terrible, and cozy restaurant (so note for your bulk winter coats!)  Came here with two gfs on a Tuesday night around 630 (it was busy around 8ish). Come early and take advantage of their happy hour where we got to snack on deviled eggs (not my favorite thing), and shrimp chips with everything bagel type toppings and creme fraiche (very yummy), and a glass of dry Italian red wine for $6! Most items on the HH were around that price, which is such a good deal. For dinner, Mon-Thurs they do a "Taste of Tuome" where one could opt to a tasting of 3 courses. They do put most of their greatest hits on this menu which is nice. We decided to just share a bunch of the dishes- all pretty good. Here's the rundown: - Perfectly grilled octopus in XO - Octopus was perfectly grilled but a bit small to share, and the XO butter didn't really shine through. The octopus could have used more flavor as well... -Famous Snow crab noodles - deliciously creamy with a good helping of meat of snow crab. They also take it all out on the shell, which is nice so you eat mess-free -The chicken- so good!! I love a good perfectly cooked, seared chicken. A good chunk of dark and white meat- perfectly salted, crispy on the outside, and juicy on the inside. Served over a stew of rice which was supposed to be like congee.. but kinda not. Wish they added a bit more veggies (think it was bok choy) on this -The lobster for two - incredibly rich. This wasn't my favorite because the sauce was a bit sweet and the chow fun noodles a bit too saturated with that flavor, and it was very rice. The grilled bread as an accompanying item was good. The tripe addition (for flavor) was not my fave and I felt the delicate flavor of the lobster did not go throughAfter food, drinks, tax, tip, came to about $80 ish pp.  Highly recommend the shrimp chips, chicken, snow crab noodles as the home runs here.

Had the octopus and the pig out for two. The octopus was the best I've ever had. Really delicious with the pairing if the whip. The pig out for two was the main reason we came here, the noodles were a bit too spicy for me. The noodles had great texture. Chewy and thick. But I think if the noodles could be  a lighter and refreshing flavoring to pair with the heavy pork belly it would be even more amazing!!!

Most savory dishes I ever had BY FAR. We ordered 2 appetizers: shrimp and chicken liver , and one main course:Pig out, which also came with noodles dipped in peanut sauce . for the side dish, we ordered Brussels sprouts and grapes. Chicken liver was sooooo good, it was sweet from honey and creamy from the chicken liver. With little bit of salt, it enhanced the flavor even more. The main dish "pig out" came out in cute cube shape. The meat was Very juicy and soft, and the top was crispy(pork skin). Everyone should go and taste this, such a memorable dish!!The Brussels sprouts were little too salty for us, but the sweetness from the grapes made it little better!!Overall, 4.5/5!!

I came here for my birthday dinner and thought the meal/experience were both incredible. The venue is very nice -- dimly lit, wooden tables, and quite small/intimate. It was the food that stood out though.For appetizers, we got the fried chicken, octopus, and mushroom. The fried chicken was especially good, but everything was just REALLY well-cooked -- flavors that were nuanced/complex.The main courses were just as good. The snow crab is a MUST -- it is such a simple yet incredible dish. The striped bass is also very good.The eggplant side was also very very good.The place is definitely pricey, but it's a really good meal and a great place to go when you're looking for a nice night out.

Great experience and food tastes good. I'm usually not a fan of Asian fusion food and but I would recommend Tuome if you haven't tried it. Price is a little on the steeper side, but it's a good choice for special occasions.

Snow crab noodle is phenomenal. Pig out for tow is also amazing. This restaurant is a MUST. We came here the night before thanksgiving so it wasn't so crowded at all and me and my friend really enjoyed our night. Definitely will come back soon.

Pretty good Pig Out for Two.There were 10 pieces so each of us each got 5. The pork cubes were crunchy outside, but fell apart just like pulled pork after a couple bites. It got the texture of pulled pork, but had fatty and duck-y taste. Pretty fun to eat. I thought 5 pieces per person were just right because anymore would be too greasy for us. The side salad with longan (or lychee?) was also good!The noodles had good hoisin sauce too.About $80 for this. It took about a 20 mins wait for them to serve Pig Out for Two. We reserved on Opentable for 2 at 7PM, and the ambiance was quite intimate, and a little dark.

I found this place on Instagram, so already I knew it would be hyped. My friend walked in and put her name down on a Thursday night and we waited about an hour and 15 to get seated. The hostess was really nice though and offered wine on the house, which we turned down since we don't drink. They offered a bottle of sparkling water in exchange. The waitress came over and took our orders and warned the entrees would take 25 minutes to come out since we didn't order appetizers.... and she was right.  Now for the food:The menu is a decent size -- some nice options (but not if you're a vegetarian -- only the 2 sides were veggie) I ordered the snow crab pasta with dashi butter and it was very delicious. The pasta was definitely made on site - it had a pleasant chewy texture. Portion size was good too -- you don't leave too stuffed. The chicken dish was flakey on the outside and tender on the inside (but a little pink!)

Tasty, delicious, great service! We ordered the pig out and snow crab pasta with dashi sauce. The pork was crispy, tasty but itself, comes with fresh salad and noodle with peanut sauce, surprisingly goes really well together. Pasta was perfectly cooked.

This is one of the most unpleasant restaurant experiences I have ever had in NYC.  The food took over an hour to come and when we finally spoke with the manager to find out the status, his apology was to say "we are busy".  He then refused to give us a second bowl of "complimentary popcorn" and was extremely argumentative saying it only had been 25 minutes. While the food was decent, it was extremely expensive and a tiny portion size.  To sum it up, you would be doing yourself, your appetite and your peace of mind a disservice by going to this restaurant.

If you're anything like me, you'll take a look at the menu, their yelp page and simple googling only to come out more mystified as to how this place is considered Asian Fusion/Chinese. Walking into Tuome is no different, especially as you're greeted with staff from all around the world... Was that an Australian accent I heard? Did I see anyone owning up to their Chinese heritage at this Chinese restaurant? Besides confusement regarding what type of food this is, everything else about the restaurant is on point. Tuome is a great place to come with a few friends and share a number of items. You'll want to order a tad more than you think you want, since the appetizers are small.I have to call out their Pig Out For Two, since this was the main reason we came to Tuome. My friend watched a youtube video on the making of the Pig Out and got stoked about food that takes over 48 hours to cook.... so of course we ordered it when we got there. I have to say, I don't get it.... I've never been a huge pork fan, but if we're talking ribs, pulled pork, or a pork bun, I'm all in... but the Pig out just wasn't for me... I'm sure it's a delicacy for some, but unless you're into Pork, you don't need to get the IT item on the menu. On the other hand, the Snow Crab Noodles were out of this world. Like a creamy alfredo sauce (but better) topped with delicious Crab. If you like Seafood and Pasta, that's the way to go.Here's my rating of everything we did eat that night:1) Snow Crab2) Scallops3) Octopus4) Mashed Potatoes with Shallots5) Pig out for Two
I cannot begin to explain how amazing the food is here! At first you might think the servings are small, but the flavors are so rich that it honestly makes up for it. The pork is AMAZING. 10/10

Very tiny place and a little bit hard to find but love the atmosphere and food! Went during restaurant week and was totally obsessed with the chicken liver mousse and snow crab noodles- unbelievable everything was so tasty!! Love the hand pulled noodles! Will come back!

Whenever I travel to NYC it's usually to shop and eat! It happened to be restaurant wk the wknd of my visit (lucky me) so my friend surprised me with reservations at an Asian restaurant since it's always been my favorite cuisine!Located in the east village off of a quaint st, Tuome looks unassuming from the exterior, but don't let that fool you. It really packs a flavorful punch with its eats! The inside was tiny, but super cozy with dimly lit candles and dark rustic style furniture. We were seated right away and got down to business.We decided on the 3 course prefixed menu for its variety. We selected the watermelon salad, shrimp tostadas, the pig out for 2, beignets and assorted berries.Each dish was uniquely flavorful, but some of my favorites were:The shrimp tostada: it had such a delicate smokey, woodsy, savory flavor that it was hard to pinpoint what ingredients were actually used in it..maybe umami is the word to best describe it (the perfect flavor) Pig out for 2:  had to be one of the most amazing pork dishes I've ever had in entire existence. The tender pork was was fried and seared to perfection and was so delicious! The skin reminded me of pork belly or chicharrone style. It was served with a side of spicy noodles and homemade hot sauce! Last but not least, the watermelon salad. There's just something so perfect about the combination of watermelon, mint and cheese! It came topped with Watercress and almonds for that extra touch. It was absolutely refreshing and light! It was such a fabulous meal and great company. It's an east village must!

I LOVE this place. It's a perfect sexy date night spot. It's a tiny, dark restaurant with intimate tables and small bar.Food:1) Lobster Roll - this is good but very small and, in my opinion, doesn't pack enough of a flavor punch to be make its size and cost worth it.2) Chicken Liver Mousse - AMAZING. Like insanely good. Still-thinking-about-how-good-it-was kind of good. It's also a very generous portion so it's a perfect share for an appetizer.3) Snow Crab Noodles with Dashi Butter - ORDER IT. I can't come here and not order this. It's just too good. It's an insanely delicious umami bomb. This dish is an Italian-Asian fusion at its best. Just get it.

Super flavorful food and cute little date night spot. Enjoy the ranges of dishes they have. They have reservations on OpenTable which is a plus. Place fills up pretty quick so get there early if you can. Had the snow crab noodles and it was divine. Noodles were freshly handmade and it was perfect balance with the snow crab Also tried the lamb and a side of broccoli, broccoli was probably the best I have ever had. I know it's just broccoli, but with the fermented shallots and the soup base sauce, it was a compliment in all the right ways. Basically anything you get will be a treat to your palate
The best meal we had in New York by far. The most interesting. The flavors explode with every bite. So much thought went into everything. It's like eating dinner in a museum. Artistry.

Tuome is one of my favorite Asian fusion restaurants. This is my second time coming to Tuome for restaurant week. app:    Heirloom tomato: very refreshing and appetizing. 4/5   Shrimp: very good. 5/5   Chicken liver: I had this last year and liked it very much. 5/5main:   Snow crab: this was so good! One plate was not enough! 5/5   Steak: this was not on the restaurant week menu but they offered this as an option. But some part was hard to chew. 3/5    Pig out (for two): I had this last year and absolutely recommend to everyone who visits Tuome for the first time. This is something special that you don't get at other places. 5/5dessert:    Berry: simple but a good finish of the entire dining experience. 3.5/5    Beignet: who doesn't want some ice cream after dinner? 4/5

I came to Tuome for NY's Restaurant Week last night. It's a small restaurant on E 5th and Avenue B in East Village. I've never heard of it before, but the menu intrigued me. We had a reservation and were seated right away. The restaurant is dim lit and romantic. It's a great date spot! The service is excellent; everyone who helped us was very nice. I ordered the Chicken Liver Mousse to start, which was tasty and a lot creamier than I've had before. Note: The courses were spread out quite a bit, but nonetheless, we were fine waiting. Our entrées came next: Snow Crab w/ Noodles, Squash, and Dashi Butter. This dish was incredible. The noodles were fresh and the flavors were fantastic. It was getting late, so our dessert was packed to go. I have not tried my Berry Tart, but it looked great. The prices here are a bit steep, outside of restaurant week, but I really enjoyed my experience.
The snow crab pasta with dashi butter is EVERYTHING. Must order. I thought the pork out was okay. The dan dan mien that comes with it was tasty. But that snow crab pasta tho...

Came here for restaurant week per a friend's recommendation!I was way too early and was the first patron there when the restaurant opened. However, I was greeted with warm welcomes and seated once I gave my reservation name.Once my friend arrived, we looked over the menu and decided on the Shrimp (on chip, smoked creme fraiche, everything spice) and Heirloom Tomato (Crispy Farro, Watermelon, nam phrik). The Shrimp came in a set of two's so my friend and I each had one while the Heirloom Tomato came in a bowl so I just took a couple bites. Out of the two, I loved the Shrimp a lot more than the Heirloom Tomato probably because I'm a big fan of seafood and loved the way the smoked cream fraiche complements the shrimp. If you're looking for something more refreshing, this is definitely the one for you but if you prefer something more soup-like, you'll probably like the Heirloom Tomato more.For our main course, my friend and I chose the Pig Out for Two (Berkshire Pork, Peanut Noodles, Sambal). It was a lot heavier than we were expecting so my friend and I each ate a max of 3 pieces before we decided to doggy bag the rest. I can't say this agreed with my palate due to the strong pork taste and I'm usually not big on meat. However, the outside skin was crispy but it's not something I'd eat solo without any sort of complements. I felt the peanut noodles was perfect to balance out the flavor.Finally, dessert was a choice between Berry or Beignet. I love fruit tarts so I had to get the Berry (Tart, Mascarpone Cream and Basil Seeds). It wasn't too sweet -just the way I like it!  The basil seeds were a nice addition with the mascarpone cream tying the entire mix together. Definitely give this a try.I would return to Tuome again for sure but I don't think I'd come during restaurant week or order the Pig for Two. The table next to us also took their leftover order home so it can be shared between 3 people rather than two. There are other items on the menu I'd like to try including Snow Crab and Chicken. It's the perfect place for that catch-up, reunion, or date.See you soon, Tuome!
My sister took me here for my birthday. The flavor combos are perfect. I recommend the chicken liver and snowcrab noddles. The ambiance is chill and the restaurant spacious for the neighborhood.

Went here with my husband and another couple for dinner this past Saturday night - everything was really great, I'm SO glad we made it here.  We all split the following:Apps:OctopusDeviled Eggs   - Both were delicious!Dinner:Pig Out for 2Snowcrab Chicken    - Everything was amazing, the table was split for favorites between the Snow Crab and the Pig Out, I personally liked the pig out just a tad more! Both were rich and decadent and mouthwatering.  I love a good crispy pork skin and it had the perfect tender middle.  A must order in my opinion if you like pork.  Cannot go wrong with the Snow Crab either - a very rich sauce served over pasta with bits of crab.  The chicken was also very good but it's just so hard to compete with the other two!Sides:Potato    - these were whipped with a smokey onion flavor, so unique, I was LOVING this sideAll in all a wonderful meal, start to finish.  I am already recommending this place to friends!

Wow - most incredible dinner I have had in a long time! I took my parents here on a Saturday night. We were seated in the side room, although the entire restaurant is very cozy and small. Lighting and music were great (they were playing a selection of Prince and Robin Thicke among others). Overall ambiance was chic, yet comfortable and friendly.The food was absolutely delicious. We had the deviled eggs and scallops to start. Both were light but enough to get a good taste. The sauce with the scallops was tremendous - flavors I haven't tasted together. I had the beef for entree - it was TO DIE FOR! Cooked perfectly, melt in my mouth goodness. Holy cow, amazing!!!

Had a really amazing dinner here and would highly recommend!! First off, the decor is beautiful - candles, exposed brick, window seats. We were told to get an appetizer, main, and side per person (for 2 people) but found that to be too much food. The portions were really generous. We started with the chicken liver which was so delicious. It was so smooth and spreadable, with a ton of flavor and topped with a bit of honey. We also got the deviled eggs which definitely had an Asian inspired twist. Good but not amazing. For our first main we got the snow crab noodles. Definitely a must try. They're made with a dashi butter that gives it a super rich umami taste but it didn't fall apart or get too heavy like some cream based pastas do. The other main was the chicken, which was a big plate of crispy and seared chicken on top of a really yummy bed of rice. We only got one side which was the broccoli. Again pretty Asian inspired. It was steamed broccoli so it's light but there was a miso-like flavor to it.
HUGE fan.  Every dish was unbelieveable. Highly rec:- snow crab noodles- rice side- deviled eggs- sesame noodles

I would unequivocally endorse Tuome as a stellar meal and one of the best I've had in a while. Every dish I got was a hit and essentially I am only evaluating degrees of greatness. I came with a friend and we ate our way through a sizeable chunk of the menu and both of us were very satisfied. Our opening appetizers were the chicken liver mousse and the octopus. The mousse was topped with a bit of maple syrup and was accompanied by some fried onions, salt, and a seed that I believe was sunflower. These three were placed on the side and entirely optional additions to be combined with the mousse. Milk toast was the delivery vehicle for the mousse. The flavors were great and I loved the salty sweet combo with the addition of the syrup. Our waitress even checked in and provided us more toast when we ran out. The octopus might be my favorite dish of the night especially with a string of weak offerings at other restaurants. Beautifully cooked with just the right balance in texture so it wasn't too mushy but not too chewy either. The pork xo was the highlight, fulfilling all my salty umami desires. Paired together with the fingerling potato spread? Sauce? Just made it even better. For mains we had the beef and the pig out for two. The beef was a gorgeous medium rare, sauces included a butter nut squash puree and what I believe was a bearnaise sauce as well as a bordelaise sauce. A crispy sunchoke and mushrooms accompanied. It was delicious. Pigout for two was my other contender for best dish of the night. I have tried to guess how exactly the pork was done and my conclusion is that they did a Berkshire pork confit that they built back into cubes. Then made the crispiest much beautiful pig skin I've ever seen to layer back on top so you end up with beautiful cubes. Hoisin sauce on the bottom, just enough for a bit of flavor. Then served with a ginger scallion sauce and a sweet chili sambal. This pork was amazing and might be my favorite pork dish of the year. The peanut noodles were also great. Just enough spiciness for flavor, a not too thick but still peanuty sauve and nice springy noodles. There was also a walnut and pineapple arugula salad. Good for contrast from the heaviness of the pork. As a side we also got the rice which was sticky rice, Chinese sausage (lap cheung), and kale wrapper in a lotus leaf and steamed. You've probably seen something similar at dim sum places. This was better than any I've had state side. Lastly was dessert. They served fried mantou with citron lemon marmalade, vanilla ice cream with red bean on top, and caramel sauce. You build your own sandwich with the freshly fried mantou. The mantou was made even better versus traditional ones as the chef managed to layer the dough so it ended up a bit like a croissant. Phenomenal restaurant and definitely worth a visit. I will note my friend and I came fairly early with a 6pm reservation and likely managed to monopolize the kitchen's attention for a good while so that likely helped.
just go here!amazing food. space is on the small side, but had no issues getting a table for 2 on a friday night. the lamb special was amazing.

I came here for Winter '16 Restaurant Week and am so glad I did. Writing this review makes me want to come back here, because the food was incredible unique, satisfying and worth every dollar.I got the following:Appetizers: Watermelon Ricotta Salad, Fluke Crudo with Squid Ink CrispsMain Dish: Pig Out for Two - fried pork belly, peanut noodles and condimentsDessert: Deep Fried Buns with Vanilla Ice creamI'm not sure if these specific appetizers are still available after checking their site, but be prepared to be shockingly surprised with how they uniquely pair simple ingredients. The appetizers act as great introductions to the main plates that are heeavvyy, so they're great refreshers on your tastebuds!I will never say no to pork belly, ever. I practically grew up on Korean BBQ and pork belly is  practically flowing in my veins so any time it's available on the menu, count it ordered. That being said, Pig Out for two is outstanding. Not only is it hefty cuts, but the meat is fried in a way that the top layer (skin) is thick, crunchy and so freaking satisfying on your mouth that although it's meant for two, you will steal the other half. Other half which is the actual meat has a good consistency. The dish might be a little too salty and drying without the condiment/salad pairing (which is personal preference) but the overall experience beats minor details. It also comes with side bowl of sweet, rich/dense peanut noodles for each person. To top it all off, dessert consisted of fried buns + vanilla icecream. Honestly I felt like this was one of those 'final meals' you choose before death-- probably from being too full but certainly happy.

3.5 to be fair.We decided not to do their tasting ($45 for 3 courses), as we really wanted to try the snow crab noodles and pork for 2 entrees. We thought we wouldn't have enough food, but were overwhelmingly full by the end of the meal. Both dishes were extremely rich and heavy. Thus, I would recommend getting either one of the dishes and pairing it with something lighter.The snow crab noodles was buttery, rich and heavenly. Generous chunks of crabs were sprinkled across the chewy noodles that were drenched in a creamy, buttery sauce. Absolutely a must-order!I didn't really enjoy the pig out for 2 as I thought it was overwhelmingly oily. The pork reminded me of the roast pork at a Chinese restaurant. However, the meat was a bit unusual as it was shredded and mushed together, topped with the super oily/crispy pig skin. I couldn't handle eating more than 2 pieces of this pork. I appreciated the balance of a salad that came with the dish (loaded with refreshing pineapples chunks and walnuts), while the spicy peanut noodles was too heavy to compliment the pork.In all, I think my review is a bit bias as I only had 2 dishes and the pig out for 2 was just too much for my liking.
I'll always come back for the 'pig out'. Great to share with another person, and good selection of cheap/high end wine.
The food is delicious, great service, but pricey for small portions.  I will be going back soon!

This place is great!  The pig out for two is a must have....good to split amongst more tho because it is very rich!   I loved the dim sum passed around during Friday evening....nice touch;). And the beignets took me back to Nola!!

Dinner here for four was delish!Ambience 3.5*: Sexy vibe but tables are cramped. Nice if you like eavesdropping, a pain if you don't feel like dining with strangers.Food: 4.5*: Everything we ordered was great. Standouts: SNOW CRAB PASTA (omg pure butter sauce and noodles had the perfect bite) and the pig out for 2 which was filling and delicious. Friends liked the crispy deviled egg app and broccoli side, but felt that the beef entree was a tad underdone.Service 3*: waitress was kind and patient but we had an empty water bottle on our table for at least 20 minutes. Even when our water was refilled, the new bottle was somehow given to another table (?)Unfortunately all the butter and animal fat were a bit much for me (beware if you have a sensitive stomach!), but I'd definitely go back and order maybe a few more vegetables next time.

Came here for a private tasting collective supper club event which is chef centered.  Chef Tommy Chen is an eleven mad alum. We had an 8 course tasting menu. Stand outs were deviled egg (like an Asian scotch egg), wagyu beef yolk tartare, black pepper shishito grilled lamb, and snow crab noodle butter dashi sauce, and beignet with goat cheese dessert. Would definitely recommend. The chef told us a cute story about the name of the restaurant is how his Chinese parents said Tommy in chinglish "tuo-me".

Food: 5/5Ambiance: 5/5Service: 3/5Value: 4/5Came here in a group of 6 for a birthday dinner and was really really impressed by the food at Tuome! The restaurant was quite small and intimate, dimly candlelit. The 6 of us got the Trebbiano white wine which was light and fresh. We then shared two orders of the deviled eggs, scallop crudo, snow crab + noodles, lamb, pig out, broccoli, and maitake. EVERYTHING WAS DELICIOUS. My personal favorites were the deviled eggs, snow crab + noodles, and maitake. The amuse bouche was everything ricotta + taro chips.. tasted like an everything bagel and was very tasty!Deviled eggs - 3 to an order; the hard boiled eggs were battered and deep fried, and I really like the chili oil flavorScallop crudo - light, citrusy, pretty tastySnow crab + noodles - literally delicious; noodles were so well-cooked and flavorful, with snow crab sprinkled on topLamb - ridiculously tender!! I'm not even normally a lamb fan but this was truly deliciousPig out - too oily imo, with a very very crispy and oil skin, but the pork meat itself was pulled or pounded or something; came with salad and these yummy noodlesBroccoli - solidMaitake - crispy mushrooms that came with this delicious cream on top (onion soubise)The only sore spot of the night was our waitress... she was very down to business, no pleasantries, and seemed stressed out / didn't want to really answer our questions.WOULD DEFINITELY COME BACK. Defs a pricier dinner though.How likely would I be to recommend to a family/friend? 9!!
Outstanding ! Really enjoyed everything about this place Deviled eggs a mustSnow crab and noodles Pork Yummie

I came here as part of a dinner club and had an 8 course east meets west feast!!!The food was INCREDIBLE!The Feast Lineup: (rating 1-5)Deviled Egg  --great crunch with a touch of chili heat. YUM  4Tartare -wagyu beef with three hour yolk and lemongrass--deliciously fresh but I didn't taste any lemongrass.  4Shrimp Toastwith wasabi aioli and chives --omg this is amazing! lightly fried with a burst of shrimp!  4.5Lambwith black pepper sauce and shishito--OMG WHAT!!!!!!!!!!!!!! This is what a 5 tastes like!Dumplingwith parmesan and herb sauce--good but lacked flavor excitement  3Pig Outwith berkshire pork, condiments, and star fruit--This pork was outstanding! The crunch is out of this world and the hot sauce put it over the top for me.  4.5Snow Crabwith noodle, squash, and dashi butter--very good 3.5Beignetice cream sandwich with goat's milk caramel--its not new orleans but it was damn good!  4Can't wait to return

service was very friendly, cocktails were awesome!! although the entire staff seemed nervous, almost scared to make mistakes. food was great, a bit salty - this is the first time i've been to this caliber of dining where the plates were seasoned this way. maybe we just dined on an "off" day. weird vibes all around.

This was our second time enjoying dinner at Tuome, and it was just as good, if not better than we remembered! Although some dishes were changed that I would have loved to of tried again (lamb shank!), but the menu was incredible none the less! We had a variety of dishes from the chicken liver, to the octopus, and can't forget the lobster roll as well. The main course we decided on the pig out for 2 (a can't miss, and menu staple), as well as the stone crab noodles. The pork was insanely good! And the crab noodles did not disappoint either, and the apps were all just as complex and flavor packed as the mains! The favorite of ours was definitely the chicken liver, the flavors they had created with the maple, as well as the little accoutrements served alongside were simply stunning! Can't wait to dine with Tuome again!

Made a last minute reservation to try the restaurant week menu, this spot was on my list of places to try. Was offered a seat in between other diners, requested the one near the wall and the waitress obliged. (Why didn't they just offer the corner seat to begin with?) Food was great! Don't remember much about the cocktail but did order one to try. Definitely recommend!

I had dinner here last Friday with three other friends.  It's a small, cozy, warm restaurant with dark wood all around.  A neighborhood gem. We ordered wine and Sake cocktails.  There's no liquor, but it wasn't missed since the cocktails were so tasty!It was hard to order since everything looked amazing!  Our server make suggestions with his favorites.  We all decided to share.  The "Egg" deviled, crispy, chili was out of this world.  If things couldn't get any taster, we had the "Mataki"!  Wow, taste buds blown!  I was also a big fan of the "Snow Crab".  We had a fairly late reservation, but still left before closing.  The staff didn't make us feel rushed.  We had a nice, scrumptious, leisurely.  I can't wait to come back!!

Small restaurant, very East Village. Great food. The fried deviled eggs are to die for, and so are the snow crab noodles and kale rice. Wine list is very decent at reasonable prices. Highly recommend going.

GREAT place! This place is as good as it gets for sure. Had an intimate girls night and literally every dish we got was just perfect!When other reviewers tell you to get the snow crab noodles and the pig out, YOU LISTEN. Because, these just became my two favorite dishes in NYC. I would definitely return here to literally "pig-out" on all of their other menus they have to offer. They also gave us complimentary soup-type corn dish that I couldn't make out what it was, but it was SO good.The service was impeccable, and the food was perfect, making my overall dining experience as 5 star worthy response.

Very cute. Very intimate. Dimmed lighting. My kind of setting. It's a small place but they have two different rooms, the area where you first walk in seemed more open, but to the left, there's kind of a closed off room that seems very romantic. Ideal place for a date. I enjoyed every dish we had here, minus the desserts. The duck for two was served with mounds of quinoa, with lettuce...that was supposed to be eaten as Korean style ssam. The butternut squash soup was poppin'!!! And the beef tartare with the broccoli chips?! I LIVE for it. We both had a glass of the Brut Rosé that came in cute cocktail glasses.I need to be back.

Went for winter restaurant week on Friday. Had the tartare with broccoli chips for the appetizer. Huge portion but the meat was a little too chunky. Next was the snow crab noodles. The best thing I've had in a long time. So delicious ! And the deconstructed banana pudding was the perfect ending! Love that they put items from their normal menu for restaurant week. Excellent meal, can't wait to go back!

EVERYTHING WE GOT WAS AMAZING and I'm sure anything we didn't get would be just as amazing too. We didn't come for restaurant week but RW is quite a steal for a place as good as this!For the app, we got the octopus with pork xo, brown butter, and fingerling potatoes. Fat piece of octopus tentacle that paired amazing with the pork XO sauce with bits of bacon and pine nuts, which also paired nicely to the fingerling potatoes that came as a really smooth creamy purée. Every bite was delicious and while not a huge portion, it was just right because of the strong flavors and textures. The only suggestion I have for this dish is for the octopus to be a bit more charred! I would have preferred a more smoky/burnt taste on the octopus.For the main, I got the red snapper with manila clam and leek that was served in a milky broth table-side while my boyfriend got the beef with sunchoke, shallot confit, and mushroom. The fish was cooked to perfection and I slurped up every last bit of that milky (but not creamy) clam soup!! I have not ever had a fish dish served like this and omg it was a party in my mouth. A very light and tasty main. My boyfriend's beef was super tender and also went well with its accompaniments. I can't say much about his main because I was wayyyy too into my own to leave room to try more of his hahaha (thank god he's allergic to shellfish because I ain't sharing ... because I'm shellfish ... ha ha ... ok i'll stop now).As a side, we got broccoli with fermented shallot, garlic, and sichuan chili. TASTY AF!! That's all I have to say.In the middle of our meal, our server came out with these steamed chinese buns (bao zi / 包子) with a chicken and truffle stuffing that she said was a new thing the chef was trying out. They were $2 each and we decided to try one because everything we got has wowed us. We enjoyed it but it wasn't outstanding because I felt like the truffle taste could have been stronger (like adding truffle oil) to make it more unique. Our server came around later to ask us if we had any suggestions on the bao zi and I gave her that exact suggestion!My whole experience at tuome was super memorable and it's good to see that they really care about everything they craft in their kitchen.10/10 would recommend.
High end Chinese fusion, a new experience for me.Recommended - Brussel sprouts, foie gras, pork for 2.Skip - lamb for 2Small space and can get busy

I came here for restaurant week.  The place is charming but the seats are SO close together.The food was yummy (butternut squash soup and snow crab entree).  The dessert and drinks were so-so.  What I did not like is that they are always trying to remove your dishes!  I get it...you want to turn over the table and make more money.  I wouldn't even mind if they got antsy at dessert/check time...but it was throughout the whole meal.  They tried to snatch away the soup when we were only half done, same with entrees.  "Are you finished with that?"  ---"Um no I'm not".   Finally at the end the maitre d stood over us with clenched buttocks, menus in hand, eyeballing us as we put our coats on.  No desire to return.

** Restaurant Week 2017 Review ** Tuome has been on my life since last Summer's Restaurant Week. I had reservations last summer with a coworker but we both ended up canceling. This year, we decided to try our best to make it happen! We arrived on a Monday night a little bit early for our reservation, but was seated right away. We both pretty much already knew what we were going to get - the goal was to order two different appetizers and desserts and split them. We ended up ordering their Deviled Eggs off the regular menu. The Deviled Eggs are fried and topped with chili, which was a nice departure from your traditional Deviled Eggs. Highly recommended! For appetizers, we split the the Beef Tartare with wagyu beef, three hour yolk, and lemongrass and the Chicken Liver Mousse with New York maple and milk bread. I honestly thoroughly enjoyed both appetizers and could not tell you which one I liked more. The beef tartare was fresh and meaty while the chicken liver mousse was smooth and both sweet and salty at the same time. They're both so good! For our entrees, we both ended up ordering their famous Snow Crab noodles, which comes with a squash and dashi butter sauce. These noodles...my God. The noodles themselves were cooked perfectly - super bouncy and al dente. They definitely do not skimp on the snow crab at all, there was so much crab! Together, the crab and dashi butter sauce so was flavorful but yet light at the same time. The portion size is very generous as well. I would definitely come back JUST for these noodles! For dessert, we split both RW options - a deconstructed banana "pie" with bananas, malted cream, and goat's milk caramel and the Beignets ice cream sandwich with persimmon jam. First of all, the ice cream in both desserts was super iced. How was it so hard?! The "pie" cream was really good, but I wasn't a huge fan of the cracker/"pie" crust. The beignets were very tasty and hit the spot as the sweet component of the night. Service was attentive without being overbearing. I really enjoyed my meal at Tuome and will definitely be back outside of Restaurant Week. I'd love to try their Pig Out for Two with crispy pork belly. And of course, I definitely need to come back for the Snow Crab Noodles!

Went here with friends during restaurant week and had high expectations of this little, cozy neighborhood restaurant.  First of all, it was totally overpriced!  Come on - $20 for a glass of simple Cabernet!! :(  My appetizer and main course contained no veggies whatsoever and I don't even recall seeing any on the main menu either.  The food was just okay  The service was slow and we actually got kicked out as soon as we had paid the bill as they needed the table for another party.  Very rude indeed.  I do not recommend Tuome.  There are much better options out there.

This was on my list of places that I've wanted to try for awhile, and I finally made it here for Restaurant Week. Besides for the fact that some of the tables were really close together (I was this close to inviting myself to go on a trip to DR with the girls sitting at the table next to me while I was waiting for my friend to show up) everything else was great. Like I said, I showed up a little before my friend, and they sat me right away. The place wasn't filled yet, but by the time we left there were a few people waiting around to be sat.  While I was waiting I browsed the RW menu and the regular menu.  The one thing I wish I had tried off the regular menu was the deviled eggs, but that just gives me an excuse to go back.  We stuck with the RW menu, and ordered the tartare and butternut squash soup to start, the lamb for two, and there were two desserts so that made it easy, we got the beignet ice cream sandwich and banana.  I also ordered the east village blossom (brut rose, hibiscus, blood orange) and it was pleasantly sweet, but not too sweet.  They brought out an amuse bouche to start, which was some whipped ricotta with everything (bagel) seasonings on top, and served with some home made root vegetable chips.  So good, I could have eaten a lot more of that, but it definitely a nice way to start off the meal.  Next they brought the tartare, with a 3 hour yolk in the middle, and it looked so good!  I'm somewhat new to eating tartare, I really only stuck to raw fish before, and this tartare didn't disappoint. Next up they brought the butternut squash soup, and boy was it good.  I imagine there was lots of cream in it, but I did not care, it tasted great.  The lamb came out and it was served with red quinoa and bibb lettuce wraps. The lamb was so tender it just fell off the bone.  It was fun to make little tacos with the lettuce wraps, and the portion was huge and wound up taking some home, since we didn't want it to go to waste!  I do not like banana, and even though my friend insisted it would be easy to avoid I skipped the banana dessert.  It was like a deconstructed banana cream pie, and it must have been good since my friend polished it off.  The beignet ice cream sandwiches were good, but nothing special I would say.  Definitely a nice way to end the meal though.   Overall I enjoyed my meal here. The service was good, with our waiter being attentive, but not too attentive. The food as I said was all very good. I would definitely come back, and get some of those deviled eggs!

Tried this place last night, as they participate in Restaurant week, and wow what great food and great experience. Staff was all incredibly knowledgeable and friendly. Got seated by a gentleman who was very friendly, accommodating and helped sell the experience for us. The wait staff made great drink and food recommendations (the lamb is  MUST-TRY), and the chef made his rounds and was friendly and polite, and in my opinion one of the next David Chang-esque NYC restauranteers.It's a small, dim place with a cozy feel. There are too many restaurants in manhattan that have huge signs with average food. This place has no real sign out front, but lures people in with their creative, amazing dishes with great flavor. Very unpretentious but amazing food and service. You'd be crazy to not try this place out at least once when in the alphabet city area.

It's not you, It's me.  That little Seinfeld-ism just about sums up the first two courses I had here as part of Winter Restaurant Week.  Because you see, the food was nicely executed. It really was.  But I realized once and for all that I am just not a New American cuisine sort of girl.   Incorporating global ingredients and techniques with farm-to-table American cooking sounds lovely in theory.  But for me, the end result is often muddled.  Even boring.Case in point: My Waygu Beef Tartare with Lemongrass & Three Hour Yolk.  I got a few hints of lemongrass as I ate this, but that was about it in terms of flavor.  Plus all I kept thinking was, "Wtf is three hour yolk anyway? Because this just tastes like random raw egg to me."   Friend got Butternut Squash Soup with Coconut Foam & Chive Oil.  I will concede that this was good.  Delicious even.  Okay, yeah. I experienced a bit of dish envy with this one. As for our mains, my friend and I decided to share the Lamb for Two, which consisted of Lamb Shank & Red Quinoa with Lettuce to create wraps.  The Lamb was nice & tender.  All the ingredients were perfectly cooked.  But had the company not been so engaging, I would have been bored.  Very, very bored.  If there were Asian influences in this dish--and the  kitchen supposedly incorporates them-- I just wasn't feeling it.  The subtlety must've gone way over this uncouth girl's head. The Dessert Course is where this meal really went off the rails for me.  Banana:  "Pie," Malted Cream & Goats Milk Caramel -- The "Pie" component of this dish turned out to be some sort of shortbread that was so hard my friend and I could have used a mallet to help us cut into it. (Note to self:  When a restaurant puts quotations around a menu item, as with "Pie," in this case, think twice.)Beignet: Ice Cream Sandwich, Persimmon Jam -- I didn't get this one at all.  It presented more like small profiteroles, not beignets, with some utterly forgettable ice cream in the middle. This final disappointing course was total affirmation of my longstanding belief that restaurants should offer diners the option of ordering wine or beer instead of dessert during RW.  'Cause I'll eat dessert if it's put in front of me, but I'll rarely order it in a restaurant.  At any rate, it's saying something that I barely touched either of these, nor did my friend.Big shout out to the host, who so graciously offered to store the chopped liver I'd just purchased from nearby Russ & Daughers in the fridge for me.  Ditto to our lovely server who retrieved it.  Props also for the lively, happy vibe this little spot gave off.  Place definitely packs 'em in on a Friday night.  So I am clearly an outlier with regards to the food.  What can I say?

We came by for restaurant week on a Sunday. Normally Tuome is not open on Sundays and we had a number of service & timing issues that maybe were due to having different or incomplete staff for the day? Our meal started with an amuse bouche, which was vegetable chips and a ricotta dip. While I can't eat ricotta, my friends said it tasted like nothing so I was not missing out. While waiting for our first course (for a while) they came around with lamb dumplings and mentioned they had some dim sum dishes in celebration of Chinese New Year. The lamb dumpling was absolutely perfect but unfortunately the only outstanding item of the meal. For my meal, I had the beef tartare to start. The tartare has a sweeter profile and adding some salt helped a lot for me. While waiting for our second course (again for a while), they came around with langoustine spring rolls, which were fine but not anything notable. For the main course, I had the chicken with porridge. The chicken was nicely cooked (sous vide) but there was nothing unique flavorwise about the dish for me. I tried a bite of my friends' pig out (pork belly & peanut butter noodles) and it was decent, though a bit rich for my tastes. On the drink side, we did a bottle of the syrah they have by the glass and it was really nice. Overall, Tuome is a solid good but not great restaurant for me.

Tuome is a small intimate space with cozy/romantic ambiance.  It's perfect for a date or a small group of friends. We sat at the bar since all the tables were taken so it was a bit cramped but I was glad to get right to ordering!The dinner started with delicious cocktails and the deviled, crispy eggs - party in my mouth. We went with their signature Pig Out for two. Al dente asian noodles and crispy layered pieces of pork. Delicious but a bit on the heavier side. Unique and memorable but be sure to go on an emptier stomach.

What a stellar experience. First and foremost, big thank you to one of my best friends, Wilson Chu, for picking this restaurant and treating me for my birthday. Unforgettable night. The restaurant itself is fairly dim, and immediately places you in an alcove of sorts. Service was pretty good, props to the tall male bartender for being very attentive to us while we waited by the door to be seated. Same goes to our waitress, whom I totally forgot what she looked like or said due to how overwhelmingly flavorful each and every dish was. If you've ever encountered good food, and each bite resulted in you closing your eyes and just saying mmm. Well, I pretty much ate in the dark, eyes wide shut for 2 hours. We had pretty much a taste of the menu, ranging from the foie gras and brussel sprouts to the snow crab noodles and pig out. I strongly suggest the foie gras and snow crab noodles. The foie gras melts on your tongue, and is served with a crunchy crisp made from buckwheat. The crab noodles are lavished with crab sauce and butter, and packs a savory delight with a light amount of crab meat blended into the noodles.Awesome adventure for taste buds. Definitely recommend!

While I was very excited about eating at this restaurant tonight, I am very disappointed. After reading apparently an "ad" in Gothamist talking up Chinese New Year spots to celebrate, I was keen to try Tuome. The Gothamist ad listed this restaurant as a spot to that would have a special Dim Sum menu to celebrate the new year. Turns out, the "special " dim sum menu was simply two separate dim sum plates brought around, off the menu, by servers, at random moments throughout the meal. There was no menu stating what the special dishes were. This was deceptive advertising at its finest. I am deeply disappointed with Tuome and Gothamist for this bait and switch. I will not recommend this restaurant to anyone
The place is absolutely great. I highly recommend their snow crab Italian noodle. It is just tasty period.

Fantastic food and drinks, and helpful service. We live nearby and called ahead without reservations, and they held seats at the bar for 10 minutes for us. The confit Berkshire pork for two was unique and very good.

We had a dinner on Christmas Day. The place is cozy and nice, the service was friendly and professional, the food was yummy and creative, the highlight was Quail and noodle which came with Pig out for two. We liked the taste of everything but unfortunately didn't feel well afterwards because of the high amounts of fat in every dish we tried. But still would come back and would recommend this place to foodies.

I give it a four star bc of the creativity on the drinks and dishes but the pig out for two was a little too greasy and you really can't have too much of it.  All the other dishes were very well balanced though.
I went to Tuome recently for dinner and I loved it! Every dish is super flavorful. I would recommend the lamb for two and the deviled eggs.

Ok Tuome. I see you, hanging out like you ain't no thang, all the way on the other side of Manhattan, on that dark stretch of Alphabet City. I see you, acting like you're blending in. But you're a thing (you've been for a while), and you don't blend in with the rest. I trekked all the way from the Hudson side of the city to get here, and I was cursing my high-heeled boots until I walked in and felt immediately warmed by the atmosphere and smiles. The attention to detail combined with semi-casual attitude is really a winner here. We barely mentioned my aversion to dairy and the rest of the night the servers were very careful to discuss the various elements to the dishes that might have dairy. The wine was lovely, the ambience was just right. Not too loud that night, fortunately, and we had a lot of elbow room. We were only there to order a few light things before our dinner reservation somewhere else, and the servers made excellent recommendations. Particularly enjoyed their take on spicy, crispy deviled eggs. Tipping my hat at Thomas Chen's creations. Lovely date place.

Went with a group of four. Crispy deviled eggs were amazing as were the Brussels sprouts, mash squash (a must) and the sticky rice. Pig out for two should definitely be enjoyed by four as it's very rich.An extremely enjoyable experience. Great food and drinks with fantastic friendly service.

Came here with a lovely crew of 5 for a ladies dinner on the town. It was certainly a great experience and I recommend checking it out if you're in the area and looking for a funky gastronomic adventure. RIGHT OFF THE BAT, I recommend you opt to share everything because there are too many interesting dishes to try and I would have regretted getting one entree to myself. The pig out for two ($52) was the star of the show. The pork was perfectly crispy and paired well with the tangy arugula and spicy peanut noodles on the side. It's also pretty huge and can be split amongst more than just 2 people. I would argue that the peanut noodles are the best I've ever tried. Other things we got that are also amazing - Brussels Sprouts, Maitake Mushrooms, Sticky Rice, and Octopus. Of these, I think the standouts included the potatoes that came with the Octopus (came in a puree from a SPRAY CAN, like the ones you use for whipped cream. AMAZING), and the sticky rice served in a leafy wrap of some kind. Perfectly sticky with just the right amount of sweet. Also the tunes here were ON POINT. They were playing some throwback 2000s hip hop which I was all about and contributed to the overall cool vibes this place is channeling.

If I could give Tuome 6 stars, I would! As someone who lives in the immediate area, I can say it's easily the best restaurant in east village/LES, and the service is amazing. The food is totally innovative and delicious...I recommend the Pig for 2 and the egg!Amazing place...a definite must visit.
Listen. Here's what I need you to do. Go here, and order the Pig for Two. If it isn't the best thing you've ever eaten in New York City, please let me know - because I'd like to taste what is.

Simple ingredients and techniques to create a work of art you can eat. I had the off menu geoduck clam sashimi and tempura. So simply treated to let the clam shine through! The dashi butter noodles with crab is an experience I hope to have again. It was good til I was scrapping the plate for the last bit of butter. The beignets were airy and the marmalade was so good I could have been satisfied just eating the marmalade.

This was certainly a very memorable experience (in mah mouf) and I highly recommend you check it out. I was there with 5 girls for a light dinner and drinks.The dinner started with an amuse bouche that was some sort of apple puree with a hint of chili. This was really superb, and I felt inspired to make soup all winter long.For food, we got:The OctopusBrussel SproutsMaitake mushroomsSticky riceThe Pig OutThis wasn't a ton of food so if you are trying to have a real meal, I would recommend throwing in another main course or two. The standouts for me were certainly the Pig Out and the octopus. The octopus came with this amazing pureed fingerling potatoes that came out of one of those fancy spray cans. I typically don't eat canned food but for these I'd make an exception every day for the rest of my life if I could.The Pig Out is an absolute must. This is supposed to be for 2, but honestly it was a lot for two people (in my opinion) if you are planning on getting a few appetizers. The spicy peanut noodles were potentially the best part of the meal.The service was great, the atmosphere was wonderful and the soap in the bathroom smelled fantastic. Definitely recommend, and I'll definitely be back.

Accidently walked into this place with a friend, and so happy I did! Everything we ordered was absolutely amazing and the service was wonderful! We started with the "Egg" and octopus and both were super flavorful. Despite the egg dish being listed as a snack it was a perfect size for an app to share for two people. My friend and I both had the snow crab as our main and despite looking like it would be incredibly heavy, it was light, creamy, and delicious. We finished by sharing the Chinese beignets, which comes with ice cream, marmalade, and a goat cheese caramel sauce and with our server's suggestion we made ice cream sandwiches with the ice cream and beignets. Will definitely be back here!

LOVE this restaurant! Seriously give this place a try if you're in the neighborhood.The ambiance is super nice and low key, especially if you come before the dinner rush on weekends. It feels very intimate so it's great for dates or just hanging out with friends. Cocktails were super yummy - I tried the Yuzu, Thai chili and sake one. Beef tartare was good, but nothing mind blowing. Still worth trying if you like wagyu beef. Definitely get the sliders with brioche, the entire thing just literally melts in your mouth and is so incredibly flavorful. The portion size is perfect because you get enough to satisfy you and enjoy the flavors, and it's also quite filling.We tried the cobria and snow crab pasta. The cobria is kind of subpar; I would skip on this dish. You get virtually no fish for the price, and the flavor of the broth is just average. Not well executed at all and it was my least favorite dish. The snow crab is AMAZING. I'm not an Italian food/pasta person at all and I really liked this dish. The noodle texture is so chewy and tastes almost like it's handmade. The best part though is hands down the sauce - it is literally the perfect balance of flavor. I do wish they gave more actual seafood for the price tho. Overall - I do recommend this place, although I would keep the price of the dishes in mind when ordering. They definitely add up easily, and the portion sizes are kind of inconsistent.
Everything was excellent... we were 10 and the service was impecable ask for Brandon...
I love this place because the waiter Amanda offers transcendent wisdom to her customers. She changed my life. The food is fine, too.

As an Asian fusion cuisine lover, I was recommended to try Tuome by different foodie friends ever since it opened, and finally made my way here tonight, I'm so glad I did!Since their menu was relatively small, we didn't take too much time and decided to go with their signature dishes - pig out. It sort of reminded me the crispy pork that I have once had in Hong Kong, only that the crust was more crispy - you have to dip it into the sweet chili sauce! The Brussel sprouts, on the other hand; was somewhat disappointing - the blue cheese scent was so strong that it completely overwhelmed the whole taste. Not a cheese person myself, I would suggest to skip the course. Their cocktail selection was rather limited, yet I did like my East Village Blossom - the blood orange flavor was just at the right level, making the whole drink a bit fruity. If I had to come up with something to complain about, that will be the weird music that was kept playing while we were dining...felt a bit spooky...but that was something else. I will for sure come back with a larger group, so as to try more options!

Though the pork belly might be a bit over hyped, the overall experience is top notch. Had the deviled eggs, pork belly for two and the maitake mushroom side. Of everything we enjoyed the side of noodles that comes with the pork belly, but really couldn't complain about anything. In addition, the wine and service were excellent. Will definitely be back.

Very innovative food. We tried the snow crab noodles, the fluke, the mussels and the brussels sprouts. Most plates seemed to be focussed around a star ingredient (e.g. the snow crab) surrounded by a supporting filler (e.g. the noodles); however I wish that there was a bit more of the star and a little less filler in each dish.The atmosphere is great, with just the right amount of lighting to complement the glow of the streetlights coming through the large windows. The tables are a little on the smaller side, and quite close to each other, but that's normal for this neighborhood.A couple of minor complaints included a 25 minute delay in getting seated (we had a reservation), and the chill on your back if you're sitting at the window (double glazing would be nice).
A bit pricey but nice to try.Tried the "egg" and the "pig out", which was really innovative in cooking ways and tastes great.Would visit again for a dinner if I am around!

A very enjoyable meal. We started with the deviled eggs and octopus, which were both amazing. For my main, I had the snow crab pasta, which was delicious, but quite rich--best to share.
